text: Dark amber beer with a thick foamy light tan head that lasts a long time. Nose of roasted nuts, brown sugar, and sweet vanilla. Flavor is similar with almonds, caramel, and sweet grain finished with a mild somewhat fruity bitterness. Pretty good, but the the combination of flavors is a bit strange.

Bottle from Phil. Pours murky brown no head or lacing. Nose is fruity, syrup. Flavours are plums, raisins, brown bread. Taste light/med sweet, light bitter. Lightish watery body somehat sticky with low carbonation.

0,5l bottle. Clear deep copper/ruby colour with slowly shrinking off-white head. Aroma: Intense caramel, chocolate, coffee with slight honey, sweet cheese notes. Taste: Sweet rich malty start (with some dark fruits) with a hiding but noticable sour (bread and red wine) tone in a softly bitter mouthfeel. Well balanced and has a light oily/butterish texture too. Medium/full body with medium carbonation. Long, gently sour and bitter and a little bit dry finish. Delicious doppelbock.

Ar: Pungent, almost sharp, munich and caramel malts; herbal and dank hop character. Ap: Deep red-amber, clear; medium-large tan head with good retention, leaves a ring of foam and a large splotch of covering. T: Sweet melanoidin-rich malt up front, though it becomes a bit flabby, somewhat oxidized with a sherry note and stale nougat quality; a bite of alcohol, with a pronounced nail polish flavor; low bitterness, a bit of a herbal character; caramel and toasted malt on the finish; slightly astringent hop flavor carries through to the end, with licorice and black currant accents. P: Medium-full body with medium carbonation, finish is medium-dry. O: The sweetness and malt richness are fairly promising, but the beer does not deliver on the promise--from the nail polish flavor to the astringent bitterness to the oxidized maltiness.

Eye: Pours a amber to coke like color with a thick and regular bubbled beige head which dissipates rather quickly.
Nose: a beautiful mix between malts, hops and yeast, smells sweet and sour
Mouth: medium to thick texture, sweet, ripe bananas, sweet licorice, compote, 
Palate: sweet and bitter at the same time, dark whole grain bread or even pumpernickel, a bit burnt, forest, cooked pepper, hazelnuts perhaps, raisins
Overall: super drinkable, very tasty and thick Doppelbock, complex in the finish

Bouteille de 500 ml obtenue via Importations Privées Bièropholie (Montréal, QC) au coût de 7,00$. Arôme: Légère odeur de caramel. Apparence: La couleur est brune avec une très faible densité de bulle. Présence dun moyen col beige mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de caramel avec une pointe de céréales grillées. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de caramel en arrière goût. (Rating #7492)

500 ml bottle served in mug. Brown-red colour, short-lasting small foam head. Roasted malt, caramel, a bit espresso, raisins. Bittersweet taste. Alcohol well hidden. Soft carbonated, medium body. I expected a bit more.

Tap at the source, 27th March 17. Pours dark, murky off red Amber, big head. Aroma is caramel, burnt notes. Taste is sticky caramel, burnt caramel, malt, sweet, slightly sickly, some carbonation. Its OK
Draught at Augustiner keller Munich. Short beige head. Clear solid red light brown head. Marvellous aroma. Full malty body and a balanced bitterness.
A solid, flavorful doppelbock. Copper clear color, good mild malt, slight bitter finish. March madness 2017
A smooth malty beer. Relative to some other Doppelbocks, the aroma is lacking, maybe related to age of the bottle. Head retention is weak.

Brown bottle, 50 cl, best before 04.16, via Philippe Boutin (merci!), savoured on March 23 2017; eye: mahogany, semi-clear, no effervescence, ring of beige head, slight lacing; nose: malt, toffee, slight Madeira; mouth: malt, toffee, slight Madeira, light brown sugar, slight acridness, light brown sugar, finale in malt with presence of toffee, medium body, below-average carbonation, mildly sweet, lightly syrupy texture; overall: correct

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 50 cl, meilleure avant 04.16, via Philippe Boutin (merci!), savourée le 23 mars 2017; il : acajou, semi-limpide, pas deffervescence, anneau de mousse beige, très légère dentelle; nez : malt, toffee, très léger madère; bouche : malt, toffee, très léger madère, léger cassonade, très légère âcreté, léger cassonade, finale en malt avec légère présence de toffee, corps moyen, carbonatation sous la moyenne, moyennement sucrée, texture légèrement sirupeuse; en résumé : correct
Keg at the beerhall. Pours deep amber, nose is caramel, toffee, floral, taste is sweet, malty, chewy.

0.5l bottle from tengelmann in münchen. pours a clear chestnut/mahogany with a medium white head, aroma of caramel, dark fruits, prunes, nuts. malty flavour, raisins, dates, bread. flat carbonation, sweetish. alcohol is somewhat hidden.
Dark brown color with off-white head. Aroma is sweet malt. Taste is fruity malts white a good balance.

Light brown, reddish hints, lots of bubbles. Average mocha head, ok retention and some lacing. Aroma shows delicate roasted malts (with a touch of ground coffee), caramel and slight fruitiness. Average intensity. Taste is obviously malty with caramel and dark bread, again a slight roasted malts note and delicate dark/dried fruit hints. Overall pleasantly sweet with just the right amount of roasted malts to bring enough balance. Slighty warming with still perfectly hidden alcohol. Medium bodied with medium to high carbonation (pretty high per style i guess), quite creamy but still goes down very easy. Overall, nicely warming while still perfectly balanced and highly drinkable. Very good.
500ml Bottle - Dark brown with red tinges and a foamy head. Malty aroma with raisins and marzipan. Malty and fruity taste with raisins, plums and dates standing out.

Bottle. Dark Reddish-Brown in colour. Very malty; nice lightly roasty malts, caramel, toffee, chocolate. Very Fruity; dark fruits, raisins, plums, some sour berries. Warming alcohol. Sweet malty fruity throughout. Enjoyable beer! (2010-02)

Bottle from Elysium. Thats an excellent batch I had here. Aroma: Dried fruit, caramel, bread, toffee. Appearance: Nice durable head, dark brown body. Taste: Sweet, lots of dried fruit, caramel, toast, bit of alcoholic underpinning. Palate: Sweet finish, low carbonation, medium-high body, velvety texture.

330ml bottle. Pours out a dark brown with some ruby highlights topped with a small tan head. Nose is earthy wood pit fruit toffee grain and some booze. Taste is more of the rich malts pit fruit toast some wood and a chocolate sweetness.

My label looked different then the one pictured here (lots a blue and gold). Pours a dark red with a quick head. Aromas big caramel and toffee with some nuttiness. Flavors sweet caramel, toffee light nutty, and just a ting of alcohol. Medium sweet. Decent.

24th November 2016Grand tasting at Craft Islington with Hackobock. Thanks to Padraig. Clear amber beer, thin cream colour head. Palate is smooth and semi dry, reasonable fine carbonation. Smooth malts, trace of paper. Mild malt cream. Dried fruits. Light finish. Nice enough.

Bottle split at the Hacobock tasting, thanks to Padraig, 24/11/16.
Chestnut brown with a decent beige cap.
Nose is earthy fruit rinds, toffee, light spice, biscuit, figgy pudding.
Taste comprises sticky toffee, fruit esters, light spice, dates, brown bread.
Medium bodied with bite, fine carbonation, semi drying close.
Solid strong bock.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: November 2016 - Bottle share at CBC Islington. Thanks to Padraig for this classic! As Augustiner Maximator, 7.5%. Dark reddy brown, translucent with a dense foamy tan head, leaving thick lacing. Aroma is toffee and quite a lot of Horlicks. Im a big Horlicks fan, so I like this vibe. Body is light, tingly carbonation, a bit foamy. Taste is dates, wheat, more Horlicks, some white pepper and booze in the finish. A tasty beer, maybe a touch thin-bodied. (3.6)

50cl bottle shared at the Hackobock tasting, Craft Islington. Many thanks to Padraig for this one. It pours a clean Amber color with a minimal beige head. Aroma is sweet and biscuity grainy. Taste is also grainy and sweet with keys of caramel and starch. Medium bodied with OK carbonation. Overall, meh

Bottle at Craft Islington, thanks to MannyG. It pours clear rich mahogany brown with a thick yellow- beige head. The aroma is musty, earthy, sweet, toffee, fudge, wood, dried fruits and toasted fruit cake. The taste is smooth, bitter, dry wood, resin, leather, dried fruits, fruit cake, raisin, warming alcohol, spice and toasted brown bread. Pleasant warmth through the finish. Medium - full bodied with moderate carbonation. A pretty great example of the style.

330 ml. Pours a deep chestnut with a ring and a small island of foam. Smells of molasses, prune, malt syrup, and touches of metallic dried grass and toasted nut. Tastes of earthy molasses, dark cherry, raisin, brown bread, hints of chocolate and earthy spice. Medium body has medium-high fizz thats a bit much for me at times, but seems necessary to counter the sweetness. Finishes with a slight alcohol warmth and an astringency that both help in leaving an almost crisp finishing answer to the big malts.

Bottle shared at the Craft beer Co tasting 24/11/2016. Many thanks to Padraig for this one. A nutty caramel brown coloured pour with a small beige head. Aroma is sugary, brown bread, kvas, nutty, brown bread. Flavour is composed of sugary, raisin, brown bread, raisin. Palate is medium sweet, moderate carbonation rounded. Good for the style. Rustic sweet bready earthy grains linger.

Bottle shared in London - thanks to Padraig. Pours clear copper with a frothy, white head. Light toasted caramel in the nose, faded toast, a little earth. Medium sweet flavour with notes of leathery berries, some wood, faint cocoa, earth. Medium bodied with fine carbonation. Dry in the finish with subtly tangy berries, earth, leather, graham crackers. Not bad.
Medium head, dark ruby body. Sweet caramel malts dominate the flavor profile, picking up light hints of smoke and spice as it lingers. Smooth.

Bottle: Poured a clear brown color doppelbock with a medium size off-white foamy head with OK retention and minimal retention. Aroma of residuals sugar and light caramel malt is pleasant enough. Taste is a mix of residual sugar notes with some caramelized malt with some light bready yeast notes. Body is lighter then I was expecting with some medium carbonation. Well brewed but lacking the complexity of the top example of the style.

Poured from a 330ml bottle. Pours clear mahogany without much head or head retention. The aroma is full of berries, rich malts, syrup. The flavor has a lot of similarities to the aroma, the sweet maltiness does accentuate the syrup character. Very enjoyable.

0.33 Bottle in the US - Funny to find that here, have been looking for it for awhile. Clear dark brown color, small head. Aromas of ripe fruits, chocolate, licorice. Strong malty body. Rather dry finish. Bit boozy. Great Doppelbock.

Les arômes qui émanent de ce beau liquide cuivré foncé tournent autour des fruits secs; raisins, dattes et/ou figues. Des herbes aussi variées quinconnues. Les saveurs sont de la même palette. Un alcool à lallure costaude, qui savère être plutôt doux. Il y a des saveurs de caramel sur une note épicée. Une texture soyeuse et malgré sa minceur, donne une impression de corpulence. Ça se boit facilement. (2009-221016)

330ml bottle. No apparent code date. Appearance: Deep brown with dark ruby highlights, clear, with a nice khaki head. Head dissipates fairly quickly. 
Aroma: Smells like a true German Dopplebock. Malty, with strong dark fruit, raisin, and a touch of licorice. 
Taste: Sweet rich maltiness. Bready, a little toasty, turning to a sugary dark fruit of raisin and prune. Moderate bitterness is just enough to balance the rich malt sweetness. 
Mouthfeel: Medium to heavy bodied, with a low carbonation. Had a bit of alcohol warmth. 
Finish: Toasty maltiness with a touch of raisin
Overall: A very easy drinking, well balanced Dopplebock. Slightly lower intensity of rich malt flavors than some others in the style, noticeable without the licorice you find in some. This has a distinct raisin character, and is very easy drinking compared to some others in the style

330 ml bottle. Pours a light mahogany brown color topped by a frothy beige head that disapates down to a smaller foamy cap. Toasted malt nose has dark bready undertones. Notes of dried fruits. Rich burnt caramel malty flavor. More dried fruit, most noticeably hints of prunes and dark cherries. Slightly syrupy in midtaste, with sticky mouthfeel. Boozy notes in finish along with some herbal hoppiness as well. This Doppelbock becomes more complex as it warms and is best as a sipper.

Bottle. Deep amber, reddish in colour with nice white head. Aroma has lots of dried fruits, toasted malts and caramel. In taste quite sweet, toasted with fruity taste. Medium bodied, moderately carbonated, bit watery in finish. Nice one.
Bottle->dimpled mug. Brite lite amber with big frothy khaki head. A: loads of malt, bread, dough, grains. T: sweet bready malt, caramel and toffee, some booze. Nice.

330 ml Bottle from W&M Wareham. Label is completely different than the one show. Poured into a tulip. Deep purplish amber color. Frothy light tan head settles to a thin lace. Decent carbonation. Aroma and flavor are quite sweet though. Earthy fruits. Lots of prunes and sweet roasty malts. Quite flavorful but a little too sweet for me.
Deep malty aromas with notes of dark rich bread. Deep clear brown with almost no head. Sweet with malty tones. Fairly full body with a sweet finish.

500ml bottle (St. Urho, Helsinki)
Lovely deep mahogany. small beige head. Sweetish caramelly to treacley aroma. Relatively light palate, carbonation was quite high, but a bit of swirling fixes that. Taste also nicely caramelly, again a bit of treacle burntness, but not articularly sticky sweet. Finish has some gentle old bitter, hops. Full, but not heavy, and absolutely no hint of alcohol. Nice doppelbock.

Tasted from the bottle. A Herman dark beer, sweet, malty and high in alcohol at 7.5%. The nose is light but the palate is stronger with a thick mouthfeel. Caramel and malt flavors. Not much hops. 

F Avey---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark bronze with yellow quick vanishing head. Aroma is roast dark chocolatel dried figs and a little booze. Some hoppy sourness, some malty bitterness and also minor sweetness. Quite rich combination of tastes. Also good body and thin texture. Overall interesting but not much aroma.
Bottle 0,5ltr: Dark brown colored brew with an ruby glow. Taste is sweetbitter with hints of banana, dried fruits and some caramel.
das beschissenste bier das ich je getrunken habe.. es schmeckt wie Soja soße. niemals kaufen!!!

Bottle from the state store 
Pours dark mahogany with a small beige head, some lacing. Aroma of toasted malts, raisins and chocolate. Flavors of dark malts, bisquity, chocolate and caramel 
Nice

0,5lt bottle @ Valentin - Curious Bierkneipe, Volos, Greece
Sweet and malty, low carbonation, for 7,5% ABV low to medium body. It lacks in taste, you just get ghe alcohol in the end. Unfortunately not as good I expected for an Augustiner, the classic Dunkel from the brewery is way better.

Bottle at home. Aroma is sweet toasted malt, caramel, toffee, hint of liquorice, raisins, dried fruits. Flavour is rather sweet and cloying with a little bitterness in the finish. Body is medium. Theres a richness to it, but Im sorry to say this is just way too heavily malty and sweet for me to enjoy.

poured a medium head of finely sized light brown bubbles and asemi-opaque dark brown body. It has a very nice medium strength malt aroma with a very good malt Doppelbock flavor. It is very smooth from start to finish, slightly sweet and leaves a slight tingling sensation in the aftertaste.

Pours a dark ruby color with a dense tan head that quickly disappears. Getting a bit of dark fruit/sherry in the aroma. Sweet smelling. The taste is sweet (but less so than I expected from the aroma). Get a bit of dark fruit. Malt. Very smooth. Very low carbonation. I have not had a dobbelbock in years, and am sure I am missing subtle hints of things. Nothing stands out in taste, but this is not to say it is bland. It is a very tasty beer from a style I rarely try.
Voldby ølmesse 2014. Farven er mørk rav med en beige skumkrone. Aromaen er meget maltet, karamel, træ og nødder medens smagen er karamel, træ, nødder og rosiner.

11.2oz bottle from Total Wine. Pours reddish amber with a tan head. Benchmark example of the style though one that I do not enjoy as much as other styles. Typical dark fruit sweetness of a doppelbock. Medium palate with a sticky mouthfeel.
Alla spina. Color ambrato carico con soffice schiuma beige. Nocciole, malto, caramello, un pizzico di luppolo; corpo medio, effervescenza morbida, struttura setosa. Esercizio di stile.

Bottle @ home. Clear red-brown color, medium sized off-white to beige head. Smell and taste malts, sweetness caramel, chestnut, lightly dried fruits and figs. Sweetish finish with a slight bitterness. Decent body and carbonation.

On tap. Pours clear reddish amber with a small off white head. Aroma is sweet malts, caramel berries, dried red fruits. Taste is similar, stronger fruity notes, some hops. Medium body, sweet aftertaste, light carbonation. Very good.
Good dark beer with lots of dark malty caramel flavors. Very little carbonation no real head easy to drink worth tiring.

Super malty without being cloying or overpowered with dark fruit flavor usually associated with Doppelbock. Foam retention thick and slightly caramel brown. Legendary brew, glad to finally grab a whole case of it!

I didn't take any extra notes when I tried this beer for the first time but I'm gonna try it again and update my comments.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A brilliant, dark amber beer with offwhite medium sized head. 
initial aromas are light caramel, rose petal, and a bit of bread and candy. not extremely aromatic, but sweet smells do come through.

flavor is dominated by sweet toffee and bitter hops in the finish. hop character is very noticeable for this doppelbock, and overall, the malt character leans more towards this being a double maibock as opposed to the salvator side of the spectrum. 

finish is bitter and crisp. mouthfeel is oily and not sticky. hop character seems fresh and very continental. 

overall, a pretty good doppelbock that lacks the bready malt complexity of darker examples, but tastes fresh and has a bitter finish that makes it easy to imbibe sip after sip.

Coming from the origin region for this style, this is about the closest representation as you can get. Nothing super-fancy here, just pretty much heavy caramel malt, grain, water, and light hops. Sweet caramel and earthy flavors. Medium brown unfiltered appearance with a flatter/lower carbonation feel.
Pours ruby red with a creamy head. Aroma is dark grains and dark fruit. Taste follows nose.

Bottle into a glass. Pours a deep red with a very quick dissipating, large bubbled head, which is disappointing. Smells of dark malts, fruits, and bread. Rich, malty flavor with a well balanced finish. Not overly sweet, nor too dry. A well done doppelbock, except for the head.
Bottle in Munich. Nice red body with big head. Roasty and toasty nose with fruits and plums. Taste of caramel, sugar. Some carbonation. Sweet finish.
Very nice beer, quite strong but still drinkable enough, malty and sweet, low head, very good but I like the optimator better

Lager-clear amber-copper with a rich tan head. Rich toffee on light fruit nose. Sticky mouthfeel. The toffee is in the flavor but more muted than what's noted in the aroma. Light fruitiness underneath.

This doppel bock is perfect and in my opinion better than the Andecks doppel bock. The colour is brown-red and the taste is like the "prune" caramel and sweet and not too dry, I mean the taste of alcool is not so strong.

Opaque dark brown with thin tan head. Aroma of hay, toffee, sherry and anise. Flavor is toffee, caramel, some hints of cocoa, medium carbonation (more than I had expected based on others reviews). Sticky sweet boozy finish.

A dark, mahogany red-brown coloured beer with a very weak yellow-white coloured head. A strong, dark malt aroma, dark caramel, bready, raisiny and grapey. Medium mouthfeel with very little fizz. A smooth, bittersweet dark malt taste, burnt caramel, bready, candied fruit and raisins, plus some spice. The finish is bittersweet and lengthy.

Bottle, imported to USA. APPEARANCE - dark amber color like you?d expect from a doppleock. Not much head to speak of.NOSE - somewhat weak. Not too much to it. I think it fits the style, but very little to get excited about scent wise.FLAVOR ? good flavot ? reminds me of siting in Augistiner brewery on the eve of Oktberfest a couple yeas ago. It?s a solid drinker.

11.2 ounce bottle from La Trattoria Bohemia, dark amber, sweet, viscous. Light carbonation. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: APR 26, 2015 50cl bottle @ Hilpeä Hauki, Kalakierros 2015. Mahogany color, thick off white head. Caramel, bread, sweetness in aroma. Flavor has sweetness, caramel, bread, mild hops. A really good doppelbock.
The bottle says it is a Starkbier (Strong beer) but it is aroma wise very much a typical Doppelbock. Good and malty aroma.

Clean reddish color with a nice off-white head that keeps a nice lacing until he end. Aroma is roasted malt, dark fruit, hints of plum and slightly alcohol. Flavor follow the aroma but not alcohol notes, hints of burned sugar, caramel and hops. Low carbonation and medium to full body with a sweet roasted finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone 4S
From a 33 cl bottle shared in Avon NC. Pours a clear amber with an ecru head. Flavors of caramel. Super smooth mouthfeel. Very tasty beer.

Deep dark ruby body with a thin off white head. Lightly carbonated. Sweet malt dark fruity aroma. Dark fruity taste with some light bitterness. Finishes wet but clean. Looks lightly carbonated but comes alive on your tongue. Feels potent at first but settles.

330 ml undated bottle served in a pilsner glass. 

Pours clear and with plenty of visible carbonation, but less than a 1 finger head despite a fairly vigorous pour. The tan head was reasonably durable.

S: Roasted grains; hints of roasted nuts, toffee and dark dried fruits. 

T: Also malty with hints of raisins, dates, dried plums and roasted nuts. Lightly sweet overall but with some bitterness. 

M: Medium+ body. Medium-light carbonation. Just a touch syrupy.

O: Very good.

Dark amber-color with big beige head that goes down quickly. Aroma is mostly wet cellar (bottom-fermented feeling) and a bit of caramel. Bready caramely taste, thick, sirupy (not as extreme as other Doppelbocks), malt sweetness, not too sweet though. Boozy, warming finish. Okay, not exactly my kind of Doppelbock. Too much pure malts and too little dark fruits or coffee...

Pours red if you look at it with light behind it no real head. Aroma is all Carmel and malt, sweet. Tastes of sweet malts and dark fruit. This is a real easy doppelbock to drink, nothing overpowering.
Hazy brown. Spicy boozy scent. Low carbonation. Boozy. Very boozy. Still pretty easy to drink.

Bottle. Best by 08/14. Pours clear dark amber/mahogany with short lasting fine beige head. Aroma is heavy on malt, toffee and caramel. Toasty, nutty, subtle berries. Taste is malty, caramel, toasty bread. Slight dry and warming alcohol in finish. Medium body.

ASPETTO: granata scuro, limpido. Schiuma fine, abbondante e persistente, di colore marroncino/rossiccio molto chiaro. AROMA:leggerissimo smaltato, quasi neanche si sente. GUSTO: smaltato e caramelloso. Poca carbonizzazione, ma con bollicine finissime. Corpo leggero. CONCLUSIONE: birretta tranquilla niente di che. Punteggio di ratebeer per me assolutamente esagerato.
* Old rating, 0,5l crown-top-bottle, 2006.  Intensiv-dickflüssiger Doppelbock. Schwer, Karamell, dunkle Früchte, süß-klebrig und immer noch süffig. Malzig-schwer im Nachgeschmack, feinherb, toll!

A very nice double bock. Sweet malty good malt aroma. Not sticky mouthfeel. Actually ideal mouthfeel. Not Carmel not burnt excellent flavor. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Schaum verfliegt flott. Geruch nach Kaffeenoten, Im Mundgefühl voll, starke Rezenz. Nicht übersüß. Caranoten.
Bottle. Pours clear brown with red hues and off-white head. Aroma is very figgy, chocolate, vanilla, sweet. Taste is very chocolate, medium bodied, silky, smooth. Great.
Doppelbocks are becoming one of my favorite styles, and this one is good. A big more syrupy and goopy mouthfeel than expected. But, flavor is absolutely wonderful.

@Voldby ølmesse 2014 - 
Aroma: Sweet and fruity with notes of caramel.
Flavor: Very fruity sweet and slightly bitter.
Color: Reddish brown with an offwhite head.

Absolutely stellar! Didnt realize this was a wish list beer til now. A little on the sweet side, but a prototypical liquid bread beer. Absolutely loved it in every way. This beer exceeded all expectations, and reminded me why doppelbock was once my favorite style. Probably the best Ive had outside of Celebrator."
Dark amber color, intense malty nose. Quite sweet, malty taste. Low carbonation. Malty and slightly bitter finish.

Bottle @ Voldby ølmesse. Pours dark amber with a tan head. Aroma of malt, caramel wood, nuts, dark fruits. Flavor is rather sweet, amlty, caramel, nuts, wood, raisin, plum, alcohol. Medium to full body, soft carbonation, light warming alcohol. 300814
Bottle@Ølmesse, Voldby - brown pour with an off-white head. Aroma and taste is sweet malty, toasty, caramel, toffee, some dark dried fruits, slight spice. Very nice!
Bottle. Sample at Voldby Ølmesse 2014. Dark bronze pour with a decent frothy head. Sticky sweet, raisins, syrup, figs, yeast, grain and sweet malts. Quite ok.

12 oz. bottle from Berkeley Bowl West. It pours a deep ruby red color. Very dark with a fizzy khaki head. The aroma is bright and fruity with cherry, cherry syrup, rich breadiness, light raisin and molasses. The flavor is thick with rich dark fruit and bread. Cherry and raisin maltiness stand out with little if any hop character. Clean and well balanced flavors. Very satisfying.
Dark amber coloured and clear. Has an off-white head, medium duration. Heavy sweet, malty aroma, toasted and caramel. Flavor is heavy sweet too.
Full, heavy beer loaded with sweet fruits like cherry and raisin and finished with chocolatey malts. Very rich and filling. Not a big fan of the style and may be treating this brew unfairly.

Sweet malty taste of caramel, dried fruits. A bit roasty. Flat carbonation. Slight bittersweet finish.

Bottle in a field in Hungary. Clear amber pour, thin off-white head. Aroma of caramel malts, red wine, slightly spicy, some licorice and a hint of ripe fruits. Flavor is quite sweet, fruity, spicy malts and a decent body. Nice balance.
Light coffee aroma with some roasty malt and lots of caramel. Finishes pretty sweet. Light syrupy consistency. Dark brown without much head or lacing. Bottle.

On tap @ BockAle. Fairly dark, but a bit clear, brown colour with ruby reflexes; nice quite lasting and slighlty tanned head. From what I remember has malty, sweet, dark fruit aroma. Malts, dried fruits, sweet (minimal hops), caramel, cherry/cake taste. Medium low carbonation, typical sticky texture, a bit of spices and a smaall hint of bitter at the end to balance. Well hidden alcohol. Extremly drinkable, a very nice german dark beer
caramel, cereal, brown, tan foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, full body, sticky, average carbonation, long finish
Botte.Dark Brown colour with small head.Aroma of raisin and caramel,nice Warming mouthfeels and sweet flavor of spicey and rosted malt,good full body and nice long taste.

Location/Date:Bottle on May 15th, 2014.
Appearance: Pours a brown red semi opaque.
Aroma: Aroma of caramel.
Taste: Caramel, lightly boozy, light bitterness.
Palate:Light medium body.
Summary: My first brew from Augustiner Brau. Enjoyable, not as big as other doppelbocks, covers alcohol well.

Bottle: Caramel brown color, light yellow to brownish low head. Aroma is malty, sweet, nutty, caramel, light roasty and fruity. Flavor is also malty, sweet, caramelic, light roasty, nutty, fruity, spices.

Bottle from Beers Of Europe [040514]
Ruby caramel brown, clear, large beige head that dissipates to thin rim around glass
Aroma of fruity caramel, soft raisin, slight bitter hops, slight metallic nose
Taste of sweet fruity caramel, soft toasted malts, some raisin, slight bitter bit metallic tinge, alcohol well hidden
Palate - Very soft carb, medium body, sweet, fairly sticky. Finish as main flavour, sweet caramel, that slight metallic hint again

33cl bottle pours a clear copper brown with some thin, lacing white head. Nose is pretty big, lots of dried fruit, raisins, dried cherries, currants, some clove, plenty of malt, a little pumpernickel, some caramel. Flavor has a ton of honey comb, some cherry cola, raisins, some orange peel, pumpernickel bread, clove, a bit of almond, some cocoa nib. Full bodied, sticky finish.

0,5 l bottle with a good looking label art design. A very dark and clear amber in the glass. Fine small head. Malt and coffie on the noise. Starts dry dark malty, with licorice and coffie, bready, not so sweet as expected. Hints of caramell in the background. Low carbonated, alcoholic warming. Nice one.

This beer shows up with quite a bit of spice accented with hits of dark dried fruit. Cinnamon nutmeg and dried fig all come to mind while the beer finished clean with a light but present herbacious hop bitterness.

Pours dark brown with medium white head that dissipates quickly.
Aroma: malt with some cinnamon
Taste: malt, banana, cinnamon, raisin and boozy warmth
Overall, good but not great

Bottle from craft beer shop Hamburg. ramata carica limpida con schiuma beige non molto persistente ma fine. Aroma di frutta, ciliege ed amarene, burro, caramello, zucchero di canna, alcool. Dolce amabile, maltata con note di caramello, tostatura zucchero candito. Corposa, calda di consistenza quasi appiccicosa, poco carbonata. Ottima doppel.

500ml Flasche. Ins Glas ergießt sich ein dunkel rötlichbraunes Bier mit geringer Schaumkrone. Geruch sehr röstmmalzig, schokoladig, fruchtig. Geschmack röstmalzig süß mit leichter Fruchtigkeit, leicht schokoladig.
Light brown/ruby in color, thin head. Nutty, roast grain aroma, taste has more malt, some caramel sweetness,. Roast grain bitterness linger son the tongue. Classic doppelbock.
0.5l bottle. Amber body, beige head. Both the aroma and the taste have a significant booze character to it escorted with caramel and toast. All-in-all a nice bock.

A real good bock beer. Not as heavy on the booze flavor as I have come to expect from other doppelbocks. In fact I really enjoyed how sweet and malty it was while still being so strong. A really good brew!
Erwartet hatte ich schon was und am Ende war es gar nicht mal so schlecht. Sueffig, mit etwas Karamell, bisschen Muffigekit und ordentlich Alkohol. Netter Bock, der recht leicht runtergeht.

Pours out of the bottle in a deep dark amber-brown colour with steady head and medium body. Aroma of strong alcohol, raisins and malt. Taste of malt, barley, dark grains, dried fruits, perfume, wheat and bread. Fruity-bready finish. Nice one.
Very good bock. Think this beats out the celabrator. Glad our Hy Vee carries some good stuff!
Sweet toffee nose with some metallic qualities. Virtually no head. Slight carbonic quality. Some smoke and some brown sugar. Dark copper brown. Decent but simple.

Dobre wrazenie pozostawia to piwo, zwlaszcza po przelknieciu. Figowy smak, alkoholowe cieplo, rozgrzewa i to mocno. Aromatyczne i perfumowate jakby. Piekna fioletowo bordowa barwa, ciekawa etykieta i ogolne dobre wrazenia. Mozna sie przyczepic tylko malenkiej piance.
Bottle. Dark amber colour with a beige head. Aroma is caramel, roasted malt, dried fruit. Flavour is sweet, roasted malt, alcohol, dust, caramel, dried fruits. Medium to full body. Nice beer.
Geruch malzig, süß und rosinig. Start süßmalzig. Mitte würzig, röstige Noten. Abgang röstig-malzig, bitterschokoladig. Sehr schön.

reddish dark amber colour, moderate creamy beige head;aroma of dried fruits (raisin mostly, maybe some figs), some caramel, biscuit and minimal alcoholic notes;taste is the same: dried fruits, intensive maltyness and hints of alcohol; correct doppelbock

Bottled, 50 cl.
Pours a clear ruby to amber body with a medium sized fizzy pale brown head on its top, which diminishes completely.
Smell of molasses and dried fruits.
Aroma ruled by molasses and dried fruits, too, escorted by a massive alcoholy background, mouthfeel is somewhat crisp and sticky.

On tap at La birreria Di Como
Very tasteful and enjoyable doppelbock beer!!

Bottled : Im not the biggest Dopplebock fan , this is nice enough if Im being constructive and shit , but this beer right here is like a glass of glue or treacle in texture . Flavours of apple . soy sauce. woodiness. toffee or caramel ? or both. some earthy hop. Despite any negative stuff ive said its flavoursome .

Bottle - very small foamy head, beautiful medium amber color, sweet syrupy malty aroma and flavor, mild nut flavor, pretty good overall

500ml bottle. Dark amber color, intense malty nose. Quite sweet, malty taste. Low carbonation. Malty and slightly bitter finish. Not very complex, but really drinkable.

Bottle at World of Beer Easton on 11/26/13. Clear red pour with a medium beige head. Aroma of malt, toast, caramel, apple and pear. Malty flavor with hints of berry and caramel before a grainy malt finish.
In bottle .. very nice beer. Aroma almost sweet. Medium body with notes of cocoa and caramel .. the 7.5% in not evident at all ... a very good beer that i will absolutely buy again

330 ml bottle poured the color of caramel cola or weak coffee, with small bubbles and no head. The smell was of faintly sweet malts and dark bread. Tasted of malt with dark fruits like plum or cherry. The palate was medium heavy, balanced between watery and oily. The aftertaste had a peppery spiciness and a faint taste of grass.

Bottle. A clear one, dark amber in color and with a small light beige head. Caramel and roasted aromas with some dried fruits and a touch of vegetables. Quite sweet flavor with caramel and some roasted notes. Full body with a soft carbonation. Lasting sweet finish. Pretty nice this one. 131129
Bottle. Amber color, no head and no bubbles. Aroma is a fruitcake type smell. Taste is also fruitcake and dried fruit
Dark brown with small off white head. Malt, dark dried fruit and boozy nose with matching flavors. Low carbonation. Long malty alcoholic finish. A wonderful dopplebock.
Reddish brown color, moderate head, decent lace/retention. Aggressive caramel aroma with some notes of bread, spicy hops. Medium to full body, somewhat syrupy, light alcohol. Pretty nice.

The beer pours decent with a amber, brown color that passes some light through it, a mild off white ring of head, and mild lacing on the glass. The smell is decent with a raisin and bourbon blend that comes through nicely. The beer tastes decent with raisin, plum, mild bourbon taste that blends with the malts well. The mouthfeel is average as the beer was carbonated okay and the mouth was some what watery. Overall, it was an average dopplebock but not worth the price of admission at 6.75 in my opinion.

Bubbly, hazy, red brown with a short, tea-like head.
Deep roasted/baked bready malts, dark fruit scent.
Sweet dark fruit, prunes, raisin....flavor.
Sticky caramel, molasses.
Very good.

12oz nottle .. . Shared with the Beerfoot brew crew .. . Pours a deep molasses .. . Deep grainy malts and burnt caramel .. . Mild palate, light gritty finish .. . Pretty good but Im not a fan of most doppels .. . . . Im not sure how many problems I have because math is one of them.
Dark brown-red body, thin light tan head, minimal lacing. Notes of prunes, raisins, other dark fruits and some caramel. Medium bodied, medium carbonation, pleasant semi-sweet finish.
February 2010. From bottle. Amber color with a white head. Bready aromas with malt, caramel, spice and sugars.Nice balance and complexity.
Bottle at Yesprs - Thanks. Clear amber - white head. Sweetness, ryebread, nutty, fruity, toasted, high sweetness, bread, dark bread. A bit plain.

Bottle @ yespr. Pours an amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty spicy caramel aroma. Fruity malty spicy caramel flavor with weak hints of dark fruit. Has a fruity malty spicy caramel finish.

Utterly delicious! Light, candy like nose. Rich, sweet, balanced Belgian tripel like flavor. Lacks the smoky flavor of a lot of fake German beers in the best possible way.

Great doppelbock! Pours a brown/orange color with light foam. Balanced flavors--malty (but not too malty), sweet (but not too sweet).

Pours clear brown with orange hue. Head is mostly white touch of tan. Disappears fast. Aroma is very bready sweet malt. Taste is similar: breads and sweet, tangy malt. Very little carbonation. Just a couple of notes for sure, but I'm a fan of bock and this is a good one. Prost!

clear brown, small yellow head.aroma is malty aroma is malty, slightly flowery, 
flavor is malty, caramelly, honey.

Good aroma and pour. Great example of this style. Simple, great introduction to the style
Bottle from Stirchley Wines, Brum. Super malt. Supreme malt. Sweetly, stickily, moreishly malty. Great beer.
Bottle. Thanks Sean. Pours red/brown with fading head. Sticky sugar aroma. Taste is sweet molasses and sugar. Biscuits and grain
bottle. Light brown with one finger head. Light carbonation. Slightly sweet with caramel malt. Not the most flavorful beer ever, but quite drinkable.

Clear dark amber with a full head that slowly drops to a head cover, light streaks of lace.  Rich caramel malt grows through the palate, adding prunes and mild bittering.  Excellent dessert beer, good for sipping.

500ml bottle. Wonderful brownish ruby red colour with average, frothy, half-way lasting, minimally lacing, beige head. Spicy malty aroma, a touch of hay, bread, toffee, caramel. Taste is minimally to moderately sweet caramel malty with a nuttily touch, hints of dark fruit, minimally dry hoppy counterweight; sticky palate, lasting malty finish. Superbly balanced, strong but very drinkable at once.
Dirty reddish brown with minimal head. Aroma is sweet caramel malt. Taste follows the nose.Good enough, but I will stick with Ayinger Celebrator for my favorite Dopplebock.

Had it on tap in both Augustiner Keller and Augustiner Bräustuben. Also tried a bottle version - not much difference from tap version. Classic doppelbock - rather strong, lot of malt, typical taste and aroma. I chased it for seven years!

Aroma is sweet, caramel, malt. Appearance is a dark copper, small light brown head. Taste is decent, more of a bitterness, slight toffee and caramel. Mouthfeel is pretty good, soft carbonation and sticky. Overall, I am glad to have tried this beer. But I wouldnt buy it again.

bottle by bartlebier @ rampkrot

smells sweet/ medicinal . Pours amber, no foam. hoppy, sugary. OK
Too watery. Almost light. All flavors are faint, This is a forgettable beer, but it isnt offensive. Does the job, and is a nice pairing with a cheese board. I just wish there was more here.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2016 50cl bottle shared @Post TdG tasting 04/2013. - Decent enough Doppelbock that carries the full weight of old and tired High-Bavarian traditions on its back and sleeve. Pours surprisingly watery, red-brown with almost fizzy carb, unusual for the style. Nose of medicinal caramel, venturing on cough syrup. Pronounced graininess, even pre-bread. Lacks depth, apparent alcohol. This has nothing on the original smooth Celebrator. // Rerate draughts at source 2015 and 2016: a tad rounder, but still a soggy manure and caramel bread version of what a good Doppelbock can be.

22/IV/13 - 50cl bottle @ Rampkrot (Deurne) - BB: V/2013 (2013-367) Thanks to Bartlebier for sharing the bottle!
Clear ruby red to deep orange beer, irregular off-white head, little stable, non adhesive. Aroma: caramel, bit funky, orange peel, some chloride, dried fruits, raisins. MF: ok carbon, medium body. Taste: red berries, caramel, little sweet, bitter hops, some citrus, bit of chloride, bitter hops. Aftertaste: bready, caramel, sour red berries. Not bad, but I dont get the high ratings on this one...

50cl bottle courtesy of Bartlebier @ Post Toer de Geuze tasting. Fresh.
Cuivrée presque acajou, col beige fin.
Malté et grillé sur un profil restant très allemand, pointe de caramel, léger sucré avec ici une bière qui reste dans la tradition tel que je vois les doppelbock, pas de faux goût sucré. Houblonné léger en fin de bouche qui ajoute une pointe damertume fleuri et citronné pour un résiduel doux et sucré sur la fin.

Thx to Bartlebier. 50 cl. bottle sampled. Dark red ruby with little head. Sweet German malt nose, light syrup, light iron, spices, touch sticky, very German, Taste is very German, malt, sticky, light spice, Christmas spice, some iron, bitter herbal, caramel syrup, some red berries, Bit fizzy carb. Agreeable German fare.
Tap at hirschgarten. Clear dark reddish brown color, light brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, sweetness, little alcohol. Sweet and malty taste, hint of belgian sweetness, little alcohol.
500ml bottle.  Pours dark caramel brown with a medium head.  Aroma is burnt malt, apple and toffee.  Taste is sweet toffee and apple to start.  Burnt apple finish.

50cl bottle, pours a deep mahogany with a fast-settling mid-fine beige head. Plums and sherry and a little caramel on the nose. Rich and syrupy, with notes of dark dried fruit and a hint of treacle toffee, somehow both drying and sweet, with earthy hints of oak barrel and a good alcohol bite. A dry hoppy and burnt caramel bitterness comes through in the earthy aftertaste.

Augustiner Maximator has a thick, beige head, a clear, bubbly, copper appearance, and minimal lacing left behind on the glass. The aroma is faint, but one can detect a distinct fruitiness and a bit of sweet, brown bread. Taste is of sweet, brown bread, sugar, Japanese plum, and a mellow hop bitterness. Mouthfeel is medium and slick, and Augustiner Maximator finishes mostly dry, crisp, refreshing, and quite drinkable. Although there is an underlying alcohol presence, I would not guess it is at 7.5% by just tasting it. Overall, this is an excellent beer. RJT
Bottle. Deep amber with a thin head. Aroma is fruity malt. Flavour of dark fruit spices, some chocolate and a little alco.

0,5 l bottle BB 07/13   
caramel, chocolate, coffee, roasty, floral, citrus, spruce, earthy, alcohol, brown, clear, frothy, tan foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, full body, oily feel, sticky, soft carbonation, long finish,

500ml draught at the brewery. What an awesome Doppelbock. Aroma is raisins and dark fruits, hints of alcohol. Has a very rich dark brown color with a fine white head. Tastes sweet and sour, very balanced. Leaves a fine after taste. Very good Doppelbock.

dark bottle from Binney"s Chicago.
 Pours a dark brown with lastink tan head and lace. In tense Malty aromas orf prune and fig. Rich malty flavors. Creamy mouthfeet. Fairly big bod. Great complementary flavors amd no one should deny their chosen name Maximator.

Bottle. Pours a deep clear copper color with a small beige head. Aroma is caramel and some toffee, but restrained. Flavor is nutty with some sherry notes and caramel, pleasant bitter sweet finish. Palate is medium heavy, flavorful and warming but not sticky.

Pours a deep ruby red with a sticky nose, heavy mouthfeel and musky taste. Hmmmph, ok I guess.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2013 On tap at Augustiner am Gendarmenmarkt, Berlin. (Available during lent only, from 6 pm.) Dark brown with nice red hue, beige foam. - Surprisingly aromatic, not as sweet as expected. Roasted malt and ripe fruit (plums). There is some aromatic bitterness, not the coarse bitterness of many bock beers. This is an excellent bock  full of flavour but without the aromatic deficiencies of many. My favourite dark bock so far.

Bottle from Capones.  Pours translucent chestnut with minimal tan head.  Nose is sweet vienna malt, nuts, molasses.  Tastes malty, nutty, with notes of molasses.  Gets some late notes of nutmeg and X-mas spices.

500 mL bottle bought at the UK National Winter Aes Festival into a pint glass.  Short lived head over a dark red beer.  Fruity, malty, deep and quite complex aroma.  Rich, roasted, bitter sweet taste.  A tasty doppelbock.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2013 A hazy dark brown beer with a disappearing light brown head. The aroma is sweet with notes of caramel and hints of alcohol. The flavor is also sweet with notes of caramel, but the alcohol is not strong. Too sweet for me, difficult to finish all.
Bottle: Poured a dark red with a minimal head. Tasted slightly sweet with little to no carbonation. Good Bock beer.

330 mL bottle. Dark, with a small, tan head. Maple syrup, peat, black cherries, and milk chocolate. Very sweet up front, with a finish that is a little sour and bitter, but rather pleasantly so. Medium to heavy body, sticky, oily, and a little acidic. Overall, this is a very nice beer, but the palate is a little thin and the flavor could be smoother. Still, a very good beer, worth tasting.
Great bock, right balance between maltiness, hoes and alcohol. On tap in Venice Italy. It smells a bit like dark cherries. Long lasting aftertaste, with a new taste of fruitiness

12oz bottle, pors dark amber red to medium brown with light brown head. The aroma is quite malty and sweet. No bitterness at all. The flavor is caramel gooey sticky sweet. I suppose this is a good beer. Medium bodied. But the sticky sweetness is not me.
Perfect beer. Rubin colour, easy aroma, great taste - mix of chocolate, nuts and marzipan.

Bottle to tulip at 3 Floyds after dinner. Garnet color with a surprising two finger head. As I type Im watching the foamy head quickly disappear without a trace.  Aroma of white grape juice and an earthy fragrance that I can only describe as the skin of an Anaheim or Serrano pepper. Taste is sweet malt, grape juice box, and agave. Very well crafted. Slick feel in the mouth. Tasty.

Love the foil on top. Purchased from Chris at Dutchs. Pours this astonishing honey red with a tight, smllish tannish ringed head. Nosed plums, pipe smoke, caramel apples, purple grape skins, maybe some oak, Cognac heat, and sweet malts. Very sweet, but theres enough complexity I dont mind so much. Getting a lot of plums, caramel, apple sauce, maple syrup, hops and yeast.

Bottle. Moderate malt, hop and yeast aromas of bread, caramel, herbs, cooked orange and dough, with background notes of raisin and brown sugar. Head is small, fizzy, tan with no lacing and is fully diminishing. Color is sparkling clear copper. Flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes lightly bittersweet. Palate is medium, slick with a soft carbonation and a chewy finish. A very well put together Doppelbock, with a lot of depth and character.

330, capped and foiled. Pours a murky and very dark brown with crimson edges and a dense creamy tan head that falls quickly away. Loose drippy lace. Big sweet brown bread, dried date, and caramel nose--tons of malt sugar happening there. Creamy thick body, very low carb but still pleasing. Big malt sugar mid palate, lots of caramel, soft dried pitted tree fruit, brown sugar. Mild brown bread finish. Nice beer.

Bottle. Pours clear brownish red color. Medium tan head quickly thinning out. Aroma is very sweet and malty, caramel, bread. Medium sweet flavor. Medium-full body, very sticky, light carbonation, mild bitterness. Not a huge fan of the stickiness but good flavor and aroma.

Bottle. Aroma has caramel and roasted nuts. Flavor is of dark chocolate, roasted malts and caramel.  Very smooth with only a tiny bite of alcohol.  Great taste that I usually associate with a burning, boozy flavor but this one is subdued.  Highly recommended! 7.5% abv.

A nice beer.  Poured a dark amber color with little head, which did not last.  Aroma was of a sweet malt.  No visible carbonation.  taste was sweet malt, and the Carbonation was there just well hid.  Nice malty after taste.  A nice beer!

Pours a cloudy reddish brown with a medium quickly fading tan head. Aroma of caramel malt, yeast, some dark dried fruity esters, dates, raisins, black figs fill the senses. Taste is sweet caramel malt, bready yeasty notes, dark dried fruits and some sweet alcohol as well. Palate is a nicely balanced medium body with some good carbonation. Finishes with some sweet caramel malt, yeasty bready notes, some nice dark fruity flavors of raisins and black fig sweetness with some bitter notes on the end for balance.

11.2 oz bottle. Good, thin khaki head, that noisily fizzes away to minimal. Bubbles on the side of the glass. Clear brown / red color. Moderate carbonation. Dry finish, bigger body. Dark fruit, roasty malts. Bitter taste, kinda sweet. Pretty dull overall. Sort of lightly smokey, caramel malt and light molasses in the aftertaste. With a slight bite. Lacking complexity, pretty one-sided. So far, Im finding several of the German-style doppel bocks I try to be a bit disappointing.
Clear dark copper color with large head. Aroma has caramel, some fruits and malts. Same on the flavor.
From the bottle poured a dark amber brew with a rich, thick, tan head. Aromas and flavors were by far malt, malt, and more malt. Is there a problem with that, I dont think so.

Bottle. Reddish copper with cream foamy head with decent retention and lacing. Smells like good whole grain bread- maybe raisin bread (but not too sweet raisin bread). Very sweet flavor. Thick warming- almost liqueur-like. This would be really good on a cooler evening. Im pretty sure this was one of the places we went in Germany when I was a kid- I remember liking the beer then, too ;).
Light brown reddish, small head. Caramel, malt aroma. Taste caramel, mamts, grains, raisins. Warm alcohol finish.
Bottle. Pours a brownish ruby, clear. Tootsie roll dominant in the aroma and flavor. Some belgian yeast and candied sugar flavors. Light chocolate presence but more tootsie roll-like.

330 ml bottle into tulip glass, no bottle dating.  Pours crystal clear reddish copper color with a nice 2 finger light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers.  Slight spotty lacing on the glass.  Aromas of big toast, caramel, biscuit, molasses, toffee, nuttiness, raisin, and light herbal spiciness.  Very nice and well balanced aromas with good strength; very pleasant.  Taste of caramel, molasses, toast, biscuit, nuttiness, raisin, light pepper, and light herbal spiciness.  Fairly dry on the finish; with light lingering notes of caramel, molasses, biscuit, toast, raisin, and light herbal spiciness on the finish.  Nice balance of flavors with good complexity and no cloying sweetness.  Medium carbonation and body; with a nice creamy and slightly slick mouthfeel.  Alcohol is very well hidden with pretty much no warming noticed at all after the finish.  Overall this is a very nice doppelbock.  Good flavor balance, robustness, and complexity; and very smooth to sip on.  Very enjoyable offering.

From the bottle. Pours a nice reddish-brown with very little head. Aromas of toasted malt and sweet toffee. Flavors are also rich and sweet, consisting of vanilla and raisin with distinctive malt tones. Mouth feel is silky and rich with a bit of chewiness that is very nice. Exceptionally drinkable.
Pours clear red with small head.... Has a sweet caramel aroma... Very smooth..but kinda flat tasting...if had a bit more carbonation would enjoy more

Bottle, Pours chestnut brown with amber glow. Medium khaki head and not much lacing. Aromas of raisins, sugar, dark fruit, good german malt profile. Taste is grapey, with tons of dates, cherry, and juicy malt. Finshes with a nice mollases aftertaste. Very good doppel.

Pours a translucent mahogany with a thin, white head that quickly fades.  Moderate lacing. Sweet malty aroma. Full, creamy mouthfeel appropriate to the style. Heavy but balanced malt sweetness. Very good beer.

330ml bottle pours a dark amber color with a 3 finger off-white head that settles quite quickly and leaves little lacing on the glass.  Aroma is dark fruits with some caramel and mild hops.  Taste is caramel malty sweetness with the dark fruits and a mild hop bitterness. Medium bodied with light carbonation.  Very tasty and one of the better doppelbocks on the market.

Pours a clear red with a 3-finger, but short-lived tan head.  Smells of bread, caramel, nuts.  Very Malty.  Taste is moderately sweet, with a hint of bitter and sour.  Traditional doppelbock through and through.

Bottle. Another one down the Pipeline - Thanks Tony! Consumed at home, from my Minneapolis Town Hall glass. Pours deep toffee brown, thick sticky off-white head, very persistent. Nose is brandyish, with stewed plums, miscellaneous fruit, cake, toffee, syrup, lots of dried berry notes and a bit of leather. Flavours of cake, tart berry, leather, really a nice doppelbock. Why dont I drink more doppelbock?

Bottle sample at an Imperial Beer Tasting at the Norma Jean in Jaffa, hosted by beerandbeyond.  Clear reddish brown, minimal off white foam. Raisins, roast, cherry, flowers aroma, rich sweet taste. Full body, smooth texture and soft carbonation. Nice caramel finish. Good and balanced.
Very Malty in aroma. Creamy and Sweet in taste. this is a great Beer if you are drinking one or two.

Lovely deep red.
Big, malty brew, probably a good showcase of the style. I prefer more inventive takes, some more dryness would have lifted this a lot.

50 cl bottle. BBE 05/2012.
Pours clear ruby red color with minimal head. Aroma of dark berries, caramel, malts, yeast and mild ripe fruits. Flavor of dark berries, spices, malts, caramel, toffee notes and some flour. Quite nice and malty doppelbock.

500 ml bottle. BBE 05/2012.
Pours a mahogany colour with a small white head on the edges. Aroma of sweet berries, some alcohol and grassy hops. Flavour of sweet toasted malts, nuts, sweet berries, . Medium bodied, low carbonation and a sweet, warming and nutty finish. Dessert.

500ml bottle

Pours reddish brown with a small bubbly head. Aroma of bready malts, caramel and spices. Taste is quite malty with notes of bread, caramel, fruits and spices. Finish is malty with a smooth mouthfeel. Nice, quite tasty dobbelbock.

50 cl bottle @ lusikka, BBE 05/2012
Aroma is rather malty with some chocolate and hints of coffee. Flavour is also malty with chocolate, some berries, hints of coffee and solvent. Decent.
Bottle. Color dark amber with small white head. Aroma malt, roasted, caramel, fruity. Taste sweet, caramel, roasted, chocolate.

Aroma of currants, plums, caramel and brown sugar simmering in a pan. Its a dark red beer, yet crystal clear all the way through. Very sugary sweet flavor, like rum only with out the booze punch. No much bitterness.In fact, the alcohol is well hidden, as this is fairly tame for a doppel. This is sold in four packs of 330mls, and you might be able to finish them over the course of an evening. A good starter for the style.

Bottle from mein-biershop.de. Red brown color with medium beige head. Aroma of molasses, caramel,earthy notes. Taste, plums, molasses, roasted malt, burned sugar. Alcohol is well hidden. Bittersweet finish. Good.

This is a beer Ive wanted to try for a number of years but never found on my travels: I discovered it in Aufsturz, Berlin: it isnt on their normal beer menu but I spied a small selection of bottles on one of the bar tops and decided to investigate the laid out presentation, this was one of the brews on offer.

500ml Bottle: dark ruby red body with a thin off-white head, the beer was clear and clean looking.

The smells were of malty molasses, caramel aromas that indicated the beer was going to be a very sweet Doppelbock indeed.

The smells didnt lie, this is sweet and malty (in that order): almost sticky in consistency and mouthfeel. I like the sweeter, maltier brews out there, but this tested my resolve: I really enjoyed the first half of the tasting, but as the beer warmed in the glass my pleasure began to recede somewhat. A smaller bottle would have been fine: mental note to myself, only have 330ml bottles of unknown Doppelbocks in future!
Bottle: Poured a dark red with a minimal head. Tasted slightly sweet with little to no carbonation. Good Bock beer.
Had decent hopes for this one, but came away disappointed.  This is nothing more than a hearty bock.  Sweet malt, caramel malt, thin... goes down like a Genesee bock... just a bit cleaner.

Aroma: Olives, caramel, coffee, bread, and more.

Mouthfeel: Big oily body with significant carbonation.

Taste: Very rich. Heavy but not too much. Malty character. Orange peel bitterness, raisins, cristmas cake, whisky, etc.

Finish: Bittersweet with a spicy tone.

Overall: Very good.
Ooh, this one is heavy. Darker brown pour with some dark red tinges and no carbonation.

Bottle from Bierkraft Brooklyn.  Easy drinking dopplebock.  Im going to give them the benefit of the doubt and say that it would be better fresh in Germany.  Aroma is clean weak malty caramel and yeast.  Tastes sweet malt and caramel start, metal and butter middle, salty end.  Not a pleasant finish on the palate after a thin tight soapy start. Bottle,

(bottle 1/24/11). Clear dark amber. Small off white head. Moderate bready malt and caramel aroma and flavor. Avg duration. Light alcohol finish. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Spare lacing.
Bottle.  Murky brown color, medium off white head.  Aroma of malt-o-meal and raisins.  Taste is Christmas fruitcake.  Interesting.

A: The beer pours a dark amber color with a solid khaki head that is about a finger tall.

S: Not the most intense nose for a doppelbock.  Nice brown sugar and toffee notes with a hint of fruit to it.  Some toasted malt and bread with a little bit of cocoa/dark chocolate to it as well.

O: Just an okay doppelbock.  Not as sweet and a little thinner than most doppelbocks Ive come across.

Translucent mahogany with a thin beige head, Sticky full body with medium carbonation.

Aroma: tons of rich caramel malt, complex fruity alcohol esters.

Taste: lots of sweet roasty caramel malt, warm fruity alcohol, and some salty minerality..

By itself, rather cloying and alcoholic.

Bottle.  Aroma has notes of sweet malts, caramel, bread, cereal, toffee and dough.  Deep ruby amber hue with a small foamy/fizzy head that mostly diminished and left no lace.  Flavor is very sweet.  Palate is full bodied, sticky and oily soft.  Overall a very rich and chewy brew.  Great doppelbock maltiness.  Really enjoyed it.

Sampled from a bottle at SIB. Pours a clear ruby red/orange with a small lacing. Aroma of candied sugar, toasted nuts, and roasted caramel. Flavour the same. Full bodied, sweet - but not cloying. Slightly dry.

Sampled from bottle at SIB, pours amber with a tan head. Aroma of toasted nuts and roasted caramel. Flavour of roasted caramel, toasted nuts, sweet malts and dark fruits. Well-rounded and robust body. Great doppelbock.

Medium, loose body with a sweet, sultry juicy mouthfeel. Finishes so malty and biscuity. Decent dopplebock, but I just cannot get into this style.

Id fair to say this is one of the best doppelbocks on the planet.  Nice and rich and roasty milk chocolatey up front, swishing into this slight banana filled molasses creamsicle towards the finish.  Flavors linger, mouth made happy!

Poured into a Celebrator doppelbock glass. Deep clear amber color with a nice khaki head. Lovely nose, big dark fruit notes, especially prunes, raisins, dates and dried cherries. Ludicrous that this should emanate from a lager! Vivid and luscious, recalling licorice and Sees candies along with dried fruit. The flavor departs a bit from the fruitiness to showcase creamy caramel and molasses, but theres still a significant unripe raisin note. Theres a slight metallic tinge as well, but its not nearly as prominent as in some lesser doppelbocks and the subtlety actually works okay with the other flavors. I dont get any alcohol on the palate at all, which is great. Its obviously there but the only evidence is a slight warmth, a slight oiliness, and a slight buzz. Finishes dry for a chewy beer (much appreciated). This is honestly up there with Celebrator. I cant believe how good this is. Bravo.

The beer in the glass is gorgeous ruby red, with very good foaming. Roasty, chocolaty aroma, with hints of nuts and almonds, also subtly fruity. In the further course, the hops come through a little better, some fruit spreads its aroma! Awesome Doppelbock!

Bottle in München. Poured dark mahogny in colour with tan head. Roasted malts, dark sweet fruits and burnt brown sugar in aroma. Flavour dark fruits mixed with brown sugar and roasted malts. A bit fruity and roasted aftertaste.

Bottle picked up at City-Wide in South Bend. Served in a Hill Farmstead wine glass. 

Pours a very dark brown with a thin off-white head that quickly recedes and leaves some spotty lacing behind. Thin collar as it fades down. bottled at a restaurant in california. it was a bit saccharine. kind of surprised at how well its rated on here; id take a lagerbier hell over this, though to be fair those were in berlin.

Reddish copper hue, fizzy tan head.  Great color.  Smoky caramel nose, little earthy leather. This beer is new to the Seattle area and it seems like its languished somewhere for a while before it arrived.
Big beer and drinkable. Pours a red/brown color. Roasted malts,caramel, toffee with toasty flavors.

Pours dark, little tan lacing, not much too it. Sweet taste, a little bit too boozy for me. It takes a bit to get this one down. Not much in the way of drinkablity, but on a cold night Im sure it would hit the spot.
Great stuff and one of my favorites at anytime. Had this on a train with a pal. Nice dark and malty.

Im not at all sure what they mean by "virtually no carbonation." Pours a dark, ruddy amber, with a good-size beige head. The head actually almost looks a little pinkish. Syrupy sweet, very malt-heavy aroma - some caramel, mostly overripe fruits. Take this a few steps farther and it might remind me of HotD Adam.

20-01-11 Bouteille: Couleur rubis, très limpide, mousse éphémère et légère effervescence. Aromes de fruits rouge, de vin, avec de toutes petites notes de chocolat. Slick mouthfeel, quite malty, almost syrupy, but a little flat and boozy in the finish - decent, but needs more body to compensate for the slightly overpowering alcohol.

Maximator, Augustiners Doppelbock. Augustiner is known for their helles lagers, will this one stand up to snuff?

Intriguing old-school label with a monk and a bizzilion medals and some hops. Since 1328, nice. I like the fact that it is 12 oz, get that extra few tenths of an ounce in. The top is adorned with gold foil.

Served around 50 degrees. Pours with a nice large light caramel/off-white colored head that quickly dissipates and leaves no lacing. The beer is dark with hints of ruby.

Wonderful smell! Fruity, dark, roasty, sweet; eloquently doppebock. Mild alcohol catches the nose slightly with multiple whiffs.

Taste follows the smell. It is a mighty doppelbock though the tried and true Salvator still reigns supreme. It is nice and smooth, perfect carbonation for the style. The flavors attack with a bite, this one is no-holds-barred. Alcohol creeps in with the sweetness. A rich tasting brew.

This is a great doppelbock, worth the price. It is one of the better ones out of Bavaria though not on the highest tier.

Mouth feel is extremely low on carbonation, perhaps even too low. Not as thick as a doppelbock could be. Quite good, and very drinkable. Alcohol is perfectly well covered (a common error amongst the bocks).

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2012 Very reminiscent of Celebrator in that it does not have much malt sweetness.  A little stronger in alcohol, but still very similiar in most ways to Celebrator.
