text: Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a red-brown color with a huge tan head. The aroma was sweet and tangy malts with notes of molasses and plum. The flavor was very malty with notes of vanilla, plum, molasses, cocoa and Dr. Pepper. The finish was long and malty with hints of plum and molasses and a faint medicinal quality. Thick and creamy body. Excellent.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from Total Wine Sterling.
It pours a deep amber color with a foamy, light tan head.  The nose is malty with dark fruit notes, a bit of paper, dark honey, and a slight vegetative note.  The flavor is sweet, but not cloying.  Lighter on the palate than I was expecting.  And a touch dry.  A bit of dark honey, plum, tea, spice, vanilla, and a slight metallic note.  The flavor profile seems a bit muted making me think this brew has passed its prime.  One more reason there should be dating on all bottles.  Medium body with a slightly dry mouthfeel and a medium, fruity finish.  Certainly a fairly solid example of the style and worth having if you are a fan of bocks.

Pours a crystal clear, medium brown with a 2 finger beige head that fades within a couple minutes to a thick skim. Aroma is sweet white bread crust, burnt sugar, dark toasted granola and light spicy hops. Flavor is toasted nuts, sweet white bread crust, caramel, toasted malt and a little spice. Palate is medium to heavy bodied, syrupy on entry leading to a slick finish and a light, but quite sharp cabonation in between. Pretty average doppelbock, but I dig it.
Fine head, light brown colour with lots of reddish , deep malty bready, nutty and woody aroma with a hint of vanilla. Nice!
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is brown. Aroma and taste are rich malt, caramel, nuts, wood and hops. Not as sweet as expected, but really nice.

Pours a hazy, murky ruby brown. Poured a little head, keeps a light ring. Smells overly sweet, caramel notes. Taste is sweet, sweet ,sweet.  very malty. a fruity grape taste comes through as well. This overwhelmed me with sweetness. ISFD.

@ a tasting, thanks tomer, pours an amazing red with a medium tan head, aroma of caramel, honey and some cherries, flavors of malt, cereals, fruits and grapefruit-like bitterness, feels dry with medium+ body. Very Nice Dopplebock

At a tasting, nearly no head whatsoever, very deep brown colour with lots of reddish tains, complex malty bready aroma with a hint of vanila, flavours of dried fruits, aromatic tea, winey notes and bread with a touch of oxidised notes, wonderfull long sour aftertaste. Excellent.

Pour reddish copper with a beige head.  The aroma has lots of sweet maltiness, dark fruit, brown sugar and toast.  Medium thick carbonation with quite a bit of carbonation ~ not sure why the description here says virtually no carbonation.  Begins with the aroma traits, but not quite as sweet and a bit on the medicinal side.  Finish shows some alcohol, bit of paper and a crispness that I wasnt expecting.  Decent doppelbock.
Bottle at a tasting: bread, toast, burnt toast, biscuit, weak licorice, malty, weak roasted malt notes, a bit of cherries, some tea, some earthy notes, quite rich but not heavy, really good.

Bottle. Pours mahogny with small golden head. Complex aroma with notes of dark bread and marzipan. Taste is sweet at first. Milk chocolate, raisin, fig, that kind of stuff. Some serious malt bitterness with a touch of fennel rounds it off. The aftertaste has got the charcter of a finnish dark bread that has been smoked. Smooth and well balanced beer. A very good doppelbock!

0,5 l bottle, bought at Beer Imperium, Vienna.
Deep reddish-ruby colored one with a medium foamy tan head that dimishes to a small lacing one. Caramel and roasted malt with a fruity bit of alcohol in the nose. Some cocoa, or chocolate aroma. Oily mouthfeel, thick body with the character of roasted grains, liqueric malt, sweet caramel. Soft carbonation brings the fruity tones of alcohol. Heavy beer, fine and characteristic.

Sweet, malty, caramel nose, a bit fruity, with notes of tootsie roll, black cherry and root beer. Ruddy brown beer with fading gray-tan head. Sweetish flavor with round, mild bitterness. A bit sweeter than I like but tasty in an easy way. Very likable.

bottle pours dark mahogany with a medium off white head.  Aroma is big and sweet with munich malt and brown sugar dominating.  Flavor is very rich, some strawberry, and apricot and lots of bready malts.  Sweet lingering finish with light spicing.  Amazing flavors considering its brewed under the Reinheitsgebot.  A top notch doppelbock.

Bottle [12oz] shared with HogTownHarry & garthicus -- c/o HogTownHarry. Pours a deep amber with an average size diminishing bubbly off-white head. Aroma of caramel malt, nuts and brown sugar -- Just O.K. Slightly sweet flavour of caramel malt, toffee, nuts and a bit of alcohol. Average to medium bodied. Pretty good overall.

The color is beautiful dark, red-brown, and the head is dark-golden, creamy and lasting. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, caramel, syrup and nuts. The flavour is sweet with notes of caramel, nuts, syrup, roasted malt and the finish is dry. It hides the % very well.
Strong bold beer. Pours dark amber or cherrywood color. No head and very mild carbonation. Smells sweet and tastes like a mild chocolate, or caramel with a slight cherry.

Gusher when I opened the bottle...  Dark reddish brown with a little bit of a tan head.  Sweet malty aroma with some rasins and molasses.  Sweet carmel flavor with lots of dark fruits.  Full body, thick feel, and a long finish.
ambrato carico buona schiuma discreta persistenza noaso fruttatto caramello in bocca ancora un po di frutta caramello in finale un po di liquirizia non molto amara ma neanche troppo dolce

malty delicious aroma that entices during the pour with a mysterious reddish brown , tastes lightly caramel and somewhat sweet with a smooth long finish , highly recommended and great with roast pork  , overall very drinkable

12oz. bottle served in a Duvel tulip. Bit of a gusher when opened. Poured a deep reddish brown with a finger of light tan head. Rich malty aroma with some molasses. A little on the sweet side, but it has a big malty base. More molasses and some dark fruit. Long malty finish. Smooth and very easy drinking for such a big beer.

Roasty, plums, sweet mature red fruits notes. Brushwood autumnal notes. Very nicely sparkling. Beer is well bodied, full and ample. Sweet and alcoholized just as it should. Color is copper, nicely transparente. 

Un vrai bonheur a boire, savoureux, une superbe biere allemande, bravo a Augustiner qui ne trompe que jamais!

[bottle @ RBESG 2009, Grant Tasting]
Grainy malt and hay aroma. Clear garnet with a quickly dropping, tan cover. Grainy caramel flavour with some apples and sherry-like nuts. Also rye bread. Medium body, low carbonation, nutty.
Maximator is has slightly more hop flavor to it than your average doppelbock, but it blends very nicely into the thick malty flavor and aroma of this beer. Enjoyable all the way!

~ Purchased this 12 oz bottle from Big Z Beverage in Huntington, NY. This beer pours a deep reddish-brown color with a small head that fades away quickly. Aromas are of caramelized malts and dark fruits. Taste is the same. The alcohol makes its presence but does not overpower. All in all, an attractive Doppelbock thats flavorful, relatively inexpensive and is always available. A must try. ~
Bottle. Thanks TheJester. The lightest colored dopplebock of the 4 on the blind taste test. Very sticky and sweet smell  with not much else. Same for the taste, I guess Im not that dopplebock fan.

From the Bottle at RBESG Harlequin, Sheffield 19/07/2009
Dark coloured and smoked. A little pale and malty with a crisp and slightly bitter finish.

Bottle.  Pours a reddish brown color with a mild tan head.  Aroma of molasses and caramel on the nose.  The flavor was more of coffee and chocolate mixed with malts.  Medium bodied.  An interesting combination of flavors.  Quite satisfying.

(Bottle) Reddish brown and clear. Medium sizef fizzy head. Malts and molasses in aroma. Full bodied palate with medium carbonation. Malts, molasses, sweetness, some roastedness, lightly saltiness and bitterness in taste. Molasses and bitterness in aftertaste.

Deep brownish amber color with a mostly lasting tan head.  It has a wonderful sweet malt aroma that matches the taste.  The finish sticky, lightly toasted, and leaves a slight alcohol warmth in the throat.

Bottle into a pint glass.  Pours clear red with a rather dark off-white head.  The aroma is huge sweet malts combined with bread and yeast and a hint of soy.  The flavor is big old sweet malts with a touch of salt and sour and lots of bread.  Medium high carbonation.

Bottle, bought @ Ambrosetti, Berlin.
Pours clear dark brown with a small, fizzy, frothy, off-white head. Aroma has raisins, caramel, malty sweetness, toffee and light liqourice. Medium carbonation, fat oily mouthfeel. Flavour is relatively sweet, fat maltiness, light vinious, liqourice, light chocolate, caramel and toffee. Soft hoppy finish. Sweet, but not as sweet as other German Doppelbocks.

Dark brown color with red hues. Cream colored thin head. Rich, malty aroma with a little bit of caramel. Also has a bready nose and a little like a musty basement. Flavor was malty, caramel, and king of like sweaty socks. Lasting flavor on the palate, but left my mouth very dry.
Bottle @ RBESG 09 Shefield ...Deep red brown ... sweet caramel malt nose ... big bock sweet toffee and roast suger.

Pours an attractive, clear mahogany with a quickly fadking white head. Noble hops, dark fruits and a twinge of smoke in the nose. Flavor starts with an expected sweet malty note of caramel and brown sugar followed by a little smoke, plums, raisins, figs and earthy, herbal hops. Medium bodied with very light carbonation.
Bottle at the RBESG09, Grand tasting, sheffield. Alround rating: Typically very sweet dopplebock, loads of caramel, bit herbal, some baked beans too.

Spiced apple, chocolate, toffee and ripe banana aromas. Appearance is dark brown with a creamy head; nice lacing. Flavor is similar to the nose, with some bready malt character, delicious. Palate is creamy and bubbly. World class for the style.
RBESG Sheffield 2009 Grand Tasting at the Harlequin. Dark reddish brown colour, white head. Aroma of rye, caramel, malts. Flavour is very malty, caramel, ryebread, light bitter finish. Medium bodied.

delicious, brings a real malty exterior with mild touch of nuts. the mouth feel is medium full with a full overlay of carbonation that jumps on your tongue. rich and caramel with little hops, but it doesnt need it.
UPDATED: MAY 9, 2012 Not bad....but, granted with my limited experience....I think this is a bit overrated. Kinda weak and a tad sweet.

Bottle at Delirium Café, Brussels. Pours deep brown coloured with a creamy light brown head. Aromas of plums, caramel, dried fruit, chocolate, roasted malt and nuts. Rich and complex flavour with notes of chocolate, spice, sweet malt, roasted malt, cookies, a bit matured, dark fruit and a touch of alcohol. Beautiful.

Bottled 50cl. Courtesy of joss. Hazy dark brown. Caramel and boiled vegetables showing up in the aroma. Sweet malty taste which is slightly acidic and cloying. The alcohol is quite present. Dissapointing. Thanks a lot joss!

Pours a dark and burnt diennta, the top an off-white halo.  Nose was pungent, husky barley, molasses, grains, and tree sap.  Thick mouthfeel full of malty goodness...lots of sweet barley & chocolate mousse flavors. Perfectly rounded with no noticeable flaws, this is a doppelbock to return to fo sho.

Brown/red with a thick frothy foam.  Aroma of alcohol, roasted malts, earth and must.  Leather is first apparent followed by slight chocolate and roasted barley.  With a weight similar to Spatens, this beer falls solidly in the middle of the German doppelbock scene.

Dark chestnut color poured into a pilsener glass, little head to be found but it still looks like a good beer. It smells quite malty, a hint of chocolate, smells decent. The mouthfeel is a little weird and I can;t quite say why, flavor is good and malty, a little hint of maple syrup. This was a decent enough dopplebock but I probably wont revisit this again.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-31-2009 23:06:53

Dark reddish brown with a lasting, creamy, off-white head, leaving a fine lacing. Strong aroma of fresh malt, hay and dried fruits. Dry and malty flavour slightly spicy. Outstanding crisp biscuit and bread malt depth.

Quite excited when I found this in the large map at Delirium Cafe, Brussels. Finally!.  BB 04/09. 50cl bottle. Handsome ruby brown color with a small lasting creamy white head and lacings. Nose is deep malty. Dark dried fruits, toffee/caramel. Sweet and vinous. Some dry roasted notes and a bit of dust. Full bodied and a pleasant warmth. Wauw - very nice!
This opaque brown beer poured with a decent fluffy tan head and a treacle aroma. There is a thick chocolate and plum flavor with a slightly bitter finish. Very rich and tasty.

Bottle. Poured translucent ruby-copper with a thin tan head that quickly subsides to a barely noticeable ring. Aroma was of maple syrup, honey, licorice root, slightly wood, and dark fruits. Flavor is subdued bready, caramel, slight honey, maple syrup, licorice, oak, dark fruits, hints of chocolate, orange-citric hops, and alcohol. Palate is well bodied but not heavy and has a slight peppery carbonation, and is also slightly warming.

Bottle at The Penguin. Clear chestnut with a collapsing tan collar. Must be this damned Baltika tankard. Sexual aroma of deep oily hop, yeast, blossom, jellied red fruit, prunes, Marmite on malt loaf, tomato stem, gravy granules, leather and sardines. Does categorically NOT contain alcohol, not even a drop of it. Lean, unsticky, bready bock pumped with herbal hop, Bovril, wholemeal and malt loaf. Top-drawer savoury ale, sweetish but liquorice-bitter with it. Totally get Snojerk321s tomato juice and cat biscuit references. World-beating Bavarian exuding effortless class and mastery of style. Need another pint of it NOW.

Pours dark, hazy amber-brown, initially billowing tan head, but little lace or head retention.  Little to the aroma besides some alcohol and lager yeast.  Flavor is bready, lager yeast, alcohol, and a lasting, resinous or tea-like flavor.  Thick creamy palate couples nicely with penetrating alcohol warmth.

Pours cherry amber with tan head. The aroma is as cherry as the color with ripe cherries, prunes, black grapes and fresh apricots mixing with caramel and a touch of molasses. The initial taste is very promising with rich fruity flavors from cherries, grapes and plums. It then picks up a sweet yummy caramel note about midway and grows some into the finish. A hint of earthiness and molasses join the caramel and dark fruitiness as the flavor lingers into the after taste. Mighty tasty stuff.

Smells like plums and smoked bacon. Color is reddish brown with no head. Taste is more bacon, smoke, beef jerky, plums, and caramel. No bitterness in the finish - more of a lingering tartness. Low carbonation, full body - decent palate. Not drinkable or enjoyable though - drain pour.

Bottle. The aroma reminds me a little bit of coke with a shot of alcohol, sweet with some malt in it. The head is small, light brown and creamy, rather fast disappearing. The body is dark red. The taste is malty, not bitter, very light alcoholic, quite nice for a Doppelbock. Nearly no carbonation, the texture is a little bit oily and the body is medium strong. It would be nice if the beer would have had a little bit more carbonation...

Bottle from Bottle Stop in Bramhall. Dark brown with lively light brown head. Lovely complex smell with oats, malts, caramel, cream, some dark fruits. Very tasty. Nice amount of sweetness and bitterness. Good beer.

Bottle from South Bay Drugs:  Appears as a darker than usual brownish mahogany color with a fizzy and small retreating head. A complex scent of raisin, fig and cigar greet my nose and promises me Im in for a treat. The flavor is heavily malted down and has a sweet caramel and sugar cane base of taste. Little traces of Belgian yeast apparent but not enough carbonation to keep the attention of my palate.
This beer is DELICIOUS! A very distinct caramel malt aroma and taste. Very different from Celebrator, and very, very good. I am craving this beer.

This was pretty good.  It has a kind of subdued aroma, at least I thought so.  It pours with the color of dark tea.  The flavor begins with chewy toffee and malt, and ends with an alcoholic bite with a hint of grain.  The aftertaste is sugary and pretty strong.  The only major thing I dislike about this beer is that its mouthfeel is a little sticky.

Bottle Pours a dark amber/brown color with a light tan head. Aroma is sweet with caramel malts, raisins, roasted grains and some fruit. Flavor is moderately sweet with rich toasted caramel malts, toffee, molasses, dark fruit, and a touch of brown sugar with a medium to full body and has a sweet bitter finish.

12oz bottle from South Bay Drugs.  Pours a hazy rusty brown with a big beige head.  Had a very funky nose, reminded me of bbq sauce, cat food and tomato juice all in one, not really a bad thing.  Flavor was pretty sweet.

from beerangel.de - clear reddish-brown colour with a poor foam left; solid aroma of caramel, sweet malts and a touch of alcohol; very sweet and quite thick, solid malt body; long and sweet; aftertaste of caramel - one-dimensional and too sweet

0.5 l bottle, thanks Hannu N and Timo A! Reddish color with small peige head. Sweetish, malty, raisiny and nutty aroma. Bready, toffeish and raisiny flavor with licorice and dark bread. Well made full bodied dobbelbock.

Bottled (Beerangel, BB 07/2009). 
Clear deep ruby brown color, small off-white head. Aroma of raisins, roasted malts, some hay and horseblanket. Lighter than some other famous doppelbocks, but interesting licorice flavor. Some molasses, rye bread, grassy hops and malts. Balanced and tasty, a bit sweet.
Tap at the brauhaus in Munich. Very dark brown in the stein, sweet nose, semi-sweet on the tongue, fantastic body, fantastic doppelbock.

Crushed with Jakebra.  Picked this one up randomly, but am pleased with the results.  A very, full-bodied, full-flavored dopplebock.  Very sweet on the nose, and the flavor is balanced excellently.  Its no Celebrator, but its definitely something.

Bottle 50cl. Pours an oily, dark ruby brew with nice amber head that disappears quickly. Huge complex malty body, roasted grain, dried fruits, fuitcake. Hides alcohol very well, elegant appearance. The bottle is old-fashioned and fits to brewerys identitiy. A reference in Doppelbock!

12 oz bottle.  Pours brown with an amber hue.  Head was fizzy and minimal.  Smells of coffee and grains.  Tastes of a lightly roasted coffee, chocolate, brown sugar, bread grains, and nice hop bitterness.  Very nice.

A pretty dark amber, yet transluscent pour. Quite a bit of bubbles in this one. Head closer to dark tan, different than the white head I was expecting. Aroma is basic, some malt, hops, light fruits. Tastes is pretty straight forward with those same malts, light caramel, some real light red fruit and apple. Rather lively mouthfeel. Finishes clean as a whistle. This reminded me very much of the brews I sampled when in Southern Germany for work. Has that Becks tang, not quite sure what else to call it, but many German beers seem to have it.
Not the things weve become accustomed to here in the US, but a very solid version and typical of a German Dopplebock. A clean refreshing break from heavier American craft brewer versions
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: The aroma is sweet and malty with caramel, dark fruit, and a touch of vanilla. The appearance is deep amber with a small head. The taste is like the aroma with a definite cardboard taste and medicine, both of which ruin it. The palate is super smooth. Overall it suffers from side effects that just kill a great smelling beer.
Pours dark amber brown with a decent sized cream colored head.  Aroma is sweet caramel malt and brown sugar.  Taste is sweet rich caramel and brown sugar as well.  Good stuff.

Bonus bottle from a trade.  A pure light brown/coppery color with a white head.  Very sweet caramel, malts, fruit, syrup and prune juice.  Flavor is full of caramel, syrup, fruit, cake and malty as hell.  Very drinkable to say the least.

Bottle pours lighter brown and copper with a decent off white head.  Overly sweet aroma and figs.  Nicely balanced body.  Good amount of sweetness matched by a good buttery flavor.  A bit of smoke and peat at the end.

Bottle pours out a clear, brilliant copper with a large and sturdy light yellow/tan head, and some really excellent lace. A healthy dose of caramel hits the nose first, accented by some vanilla, and a faint floral character in the background. Ful body, medium carbonation, and a smooth and creamy mouthfeel with a little stickiness. Full, well rounded caramel sweetness is well balanced by just the right amount of bitterness, A really beautiful doppelbock.

Bottle from Corks, Bristol. Clear, dark brown in colour with a touch of ruby red. Slight, off-white head. aroma of caramel, prunes, cherries and roasted malts. Flavour was syrupy sweet, with plenty of fruit, doughy malts, some warming alcohol and a decent bitter finish. Enjoyable.

Taste 2/9 Bottle. Looks: Dark cherry/ brown body with a thin concentrated top. Aroma: Roasted malt sugars and cherry and raisin. Spice and yeast. Taste: Thin to medium body. Dark fruit and yeast sour.  A little pepper and  spice. Decent brew to have on occasion.

Bottle, Carringtons, Chorlton. This sounds like one of those weight gain drinks that roid crazed body builders guzzle. Dark red colour with a vanishing biege head. Aroma was pretty stasndard caramel malt. Flavour of sticky sweet brown sugar, molasses and prune, with yet more malt. Finished sweet. Not something I could drink a lot of, but its doubtless a good example of the style.

500 ml bottle in straight glass halb mas.  Ruby red with big dense head and lace.  Sweet brown sugar caramel and mild fruit and wood aroma.  Sweet subtle brown sugar caramel flavors with very smooth bready lager grassiness and claen finish.  Medium-full body and medium low carbo.  great mouthfeel.  Very smooth and drinkable yet full flavored.  Excellent.

A great appearance, but most importantly flavor. This has a sweetness to it that I found outstanding. Not so glaring and abrasive as the Celebrator, but with a taste of caramel. Easily my No. 1 doppelbock.

The beer is a very typical dopplebock.  Aroma is malty, sweet, caramel, honey.  The appearance is true to the style, a ruby red, thin tan head.  The flavor follows rthe aroma, very sweet, up front, malts, caramel, bread.  The finish is very light hops, but it’s still a clean finish.  Very good overall, fans of this style will not be disappointed.

(bottle) pours a dark ruby colour with a creamy off-white head. aroma of grainy roasted malts, bread, caramel and light dark fruits. flavour dominantly of grainy roasted malts, with dark bread, coffee, light herbal hops and some notes of dried fruit. full body, with medium carbonation and a roasted-bitter finish.

Pours a dark ruby color with a brownish tint and a beige, average, fizzy head which settles quickly to a very small frothy layer leaving minimal but tight lace.  Nose is typical good German doppel; nutty breads, toasted caramel, rich toffee, and raisins.  Flavor is even more rich; rich toffee and raisins to start, with some figs, light toasted caramel, almonds, and dark sweet bready notes.  Palate is good; lively, more than medium, a bit chewy, but still somewhat crisp.  Finishes with the fruit notes dissipating a bit leaving toasted caramel, rich toffee, and almonds.  A very rich doppel with nice notes in all aspects.  Aside from Ayingers doppel, this is one of my favorites in the style.  The dried fruit notes were interesting and intriguing.

"malty nose"? ya, id say so. that overpowers everything. like a giant malt ball
rough brown pour, thin yellowish head.
flavor is more mellow, a bit of cloying sweetness, toffee, not very well balanced.
interesting, but my first one at least was a bit too much.
also thinner than expected.
Bottle shared by Ethan.  Thanks, dude.  Deep brown clear pour with a tiny off-white head.  Simple malty nose and taste.  Earthy caramel.  Toffee on the finish.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2010 Good but not outstanding beer.  Medium brown color with moderate carbonation.  Flavor is sweet and bitter at the same time, not as big as I would like. Smooth and malty on the finish.

RERATE 8/2010: This is actually a really nice beer.  Great reddish-amber color, nice flavor with cherry and deep malt notes.

Bottle shared by emacgee.  Thanks Ethan.  Pours a clear amber hazy maroon. Nose is sort of salty, some earthy hops and sweet malts.  Flavor is similar with a toffee presence to balance the light hops.  Pretty good.

Thanks to Ethan for sharing this awesomely named brew. Nice fruity nose to this solid doppelbock. Caramel brown body with some moderate carbonation. It has a fairly full and lively mouthfeel, the flavors emerging nicely. The malts are not quite as interesting as I would like, but there is a pleasant spicy quality that, when mingled with the hops, redeems this one. Soft fruity finish. This one is modest.

Thanks Jabic. Pours a caramel brown with a thin fizzy tan head. The nose is earthy, malty, raisiny, some caramel, lager characters, mild leafy hop character. The flavor is earthy, malty, a tad grainy, cereals, mild hop feel and some bitterness, develops a peaty flavor to it as well. The palate is very mildly carbonated with some hop bitterness. Finishes sort of smoky.

Bottle from Bottle Barn. Ruby color with a decent tan head. Aroma of roasted caramel and fruits. Medium plus body with creamy carbonation. Flavor is reddly roasted caramel with berrylike fruits. There is a light touch of heat. A rather luscious drink. Finishes dryish.

Pours a dark but clear mahogany colour with a small tan head. Aroma is so wonderful!! Nutty, syrupy and fruity all in one. ripe cherry and strawberry fruits mixed with caramel and some kind of syrup. Taste is rich of course, again notes of various sweetness and flavas of vibrant fruit. Tastey all around.

Bottle.  Pours clear brown with an average, creamy, light brown head, lasting with fair lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (cookie, caramel), average yeast (dough, leaves) with notes of dates and brown sugar; essentially no hop aroma.  Medium bodied, creamy texture, average carbonation, and an astringent finish.  Average duration, moderate sweetness, light acidity and bitterness.
Brown ruby color with minimal off-white head.  Aroma of caramel malts, molasses and some fruit.  Caramel flavor with hintsof fruit, molasses, and malts.

12 fl oz bottle purchased at Beertopia in Omaha, Nebraska. Pour is hazed brown ruby copper with a 1 1/2 tan head. Nice lacing. Aroma of sweet caramel, some toasted bread, in the back earthy hay and chemical sharpness. Taste is the dirty, toasted caramel sweetness. Some black cherry fruit sweetness is evident as well.  The maltiness is husky and present, though has an edge to it that is not entirely pleasant. Palate is medium, mouth coating with a long lingering cloying sweet toastiness.

12 oz bottle-pours a tan head and ruby red color.  Aroma is medium malt-molasses, dark fruit.  Taste is medium malt-molasses/chocolate, dark fruit-cherry, some continental hops-floral/some herbal.  OK carbonation.   Thanks to jwc215 for picking this out.

Bottle from Beers of the World, Rochester, NY. 
Medium brown with lots of orange and red. Very fragrant aroma: fruity, sweet malt, dark fruits, port. Rich, sweet, malt flavor, with cereals and caramel, alcohol, and a bit of nuts. Too sweet and cloying. Not great balance. Nice, but I really expected more from this one.

(Bottle).  Sweetish aroma of malt and butterscotch.  Clear garnet color with large light brown head.  Malty sweet molasses flavor, but avoids the overpowering cloying sweetness of some examples in this style.  Slight roastiness in the finish.  Full body.  Good stuff.

Dark ruby/mahogony beer with a beige head. Roasty, nutty, caramel, dried fruit aroma. Caramel, berry/dried fruit flavor with backing roast and earth. Medium-plus bodied. Lingering raisin, caramel, tofee. Nice.

12oz bottle, courtesy of my brother. Thanks, Phil!  Pours a slightly murky, oily amber-brown color; off-white head that readily fades.  Solid amounts of dried dark fruits, caramel, and some citrus acidity in the aroma; solid, generous, dense maltiness.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: good amounts of oiliness, nougat, dried dark fruits, and caramel; very nice texture and maltiness; excellent, perfectly balanced, and very drinkable example of the style.  Lengthy finish: toasty malts, caramel, and dried fruits; balanced ending.

Bottle.  Pours a deep dark ruby brown in color, with a very small, beighe head.  The head quickly fades to a sticky thin lace.  The aroma is very sweet, molasses, candy sugar, a little spice - cinnamon, and dried fruit.  The flavor notes are all sweet and alcohol.  It has a full body and well rounded mouthfeel.  It has a bit of a cloying sweetness to the finish.  Excellent.
12oz bottle.  dark ruby color with medium off-white head.  roasted dark fruits, bread and molasses in the aroma.  syrupy texture.    sweet taste throughout.  little bit of warmth.  K-7

Pours nice dark brown with and amber hue and a light beige head that dissipates very quickly. Wonderful sweet caramel malt and dark fruit (prunes) aroma. Flavor is similar, sweet toasted malts, with toffee, caramel and dark fruits. The body is a little lighter than I expected, but still an above average beer.

Decent textbook take on the style that is nice, but not overly complex or exciting.  Dark fruits and sweet sugary maltiness, balanced out by some roasted caramel, and some warming alcohol sensations in the finish.  A little sweeter than I like the whole way through.
Bottled. Deep amber colour, small beige head. Aroma is raisin, plum, sweet malts. Flavour is mildly roasted malts, caramel malts along with alcohol and and some mild hoppyness.
Clear dark amber with tiny off white head. Sweet aroma with caramel and mroasted malt. Sweet flavor with roasted malt, caramel and prunes. Ends sweet.

Bottle purchased at Beertopia in Omaha, NE. Pours a burnt orange with a finger of head comprised of fine beige bubbles that quickly diminish  to a ring clinging to the sides of the glass. The nose is sweet and malty: lightly burnt caramel, cocoa, raisins, light brown sugar and a subtle toasted nuttiness. Medium to full-bodied and oily soft but possessing fine, tongue-tickling carbonation and a lightly bitter tongue squeeze at the finish. The flavor is a big, sweet hit of toasty/roasted malt, raisin, toffee, brown sugar and nuts with a chocolaty undertone and a spicy, lightly resinous and mildly woody hop note at the warming finish. This is a fine beer and a nice example of the style.

Bottle brown, 500 ml
Appearance: Pours deep dark rubby red body colour with cherry accents, body is perfectly clear and carbonation is moderate, head is yellowish, off - white, reminding me of Zywiec Porter, frothy in texture, initially medium in size and slowly decreasing to small, there is a very nice lacing.
Aroma: Cherry, red fruits, some notes of plum, brown sugar, caramel, toastyness, woody - nutty touch, resin, raisin, some cappuccino notes or cream coffee, gentle alcoholic notes but making taste more inviting.
Flavour: Very juicy, fruity, especially red fruits, red wine grapes, cherries, burned caramel, Munich malt, very well build in alcohol, seems soft, fresh and easy going, wonderful refreshing  juicyness, generally sweet but essential and focused, not dull or too sweet, full taste, very well pronounced flavour with warming retronasal aromas, again resin, raisin, cherry, plum, prune. Finish duration is long.
Palate: Body is full, texture is syrupy, carbonation on palate is rather mild, finish feel is moderate alcoholic and kind of astringent - smoky, roasty in touch.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2012 Re-rate 5/18/12: Bottle sample at a Beer & Beyond strong beers tasting at Norma Jean. Clear deep reddish brown with a beige head. Sweet malty aroma. Caramel, cookies, a bit of chocolate and nutty notes. 7/4/6/3/13=3.3

Re-rate 4/13/10: Bottle at a tasting. Thanks Tomer. Clear reddish amber with a beige head. Aroma has lots of malt, toasted bread, caramel and honey. Sweet thick malty flavor with caramel, dark bread and roasted and nutty notes. Medium to full-bodied. 7/4/7/4/14=3.6

Bottle. Dark brown color with a medium beige head. Aroma of a lot of malt, light roastiness, caramel, chocolate hints and alcohol notes. Sweet flavor with firm maltiness, caramel, some toasted bread and a bit of alcohol. Finishes slightly drier with some alcohol. Medium-bodied. A good Doppelbock. 7/4/7/3/14=3.5

Bottle poured a clear reddish brown with a small lingering amber head. Aromas of molasses, dark fruit, carmel and a hint oif spice. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, brown sugar and fruittiness with a smooth slightly warming malty finish.

bottle.  pours a nice amber brown clear, with a small khaki head that dissipates to a ring.  Aromas of alcohol, raisins, dark fruits and a little nutty.  Taste brings caramel, molasses, and surprisingly decent bitterness.  Drinking goes down smooth and quick.  I certainly like this A LOT better than the edelstoff.

Bottle.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is clear dark amber to medium brown.

Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted grain, molasses, nuts, husks), with light notes of metal and brown sugar.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter, husky.

Medium body, watery/syrupy texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic.

Pretty sad.  Id bet this brewery was once great, but man, the three Ive had in the last year (including the pils at their own brewpub) have been really disappointing (none have scored above the 2s).  I love German beer, but this brewery just doesnt cut it.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2008 Pours a four finger light tan head that fades quickly, leaving traces of lace. Clear mahogany color. Light carbonation and medium bodied. Slight malty nose. Flavor is nutty, caramel easy to drink. $2.85 for a 12oz bottle from Colonial Spirits Acton, Ma.
Pour is clear reddish amber with a thin light tan head...smell is sweet and caramel like...taste is sweet with molasses and day old bread...some alcohol too...seemed a little thing...

A dark amber color, with a bit of a lighter glow; very little head and practically no retention.

Smelled like molasses and nuts as well as a bit fruity.

The taste was very caramel heavy, not an overwhelming intense taste, but the caramel malts seemed to dominate the palate. A bit raisony as well.

Serving type: bottle

500ml bottle at Reading BF 08.  In order to shake off my hangover I thought Id nail a couple of strong German beers.  Bright clear deep red colour.  Quite tasty, deep mouithfeel.  Certainly wakes you up.  Alcohol is present but not dominant.

Nice doppelbock.  Pours brown with a small white head.  Aroma of fruit, caramel, nut, toffee.  Taste is also of caramel, toffee, fruit.  Very smooth and somewhat sweet.  Finish is smooth but a little underwhelming.  Body is medium, though relatively light for this style.

12 oz bottle. Pours a dark murky brown color with a small fizzy off white head that dissipates to a small ring. Nose of spiced rum, raisins, dark fruits and caramel. Initial taste of dark fruits,nuts, toffee, chocolate, and caramel. Mid palate sugary sweetness  lingers.Finishing rather bland with small hop balance. Mildly chalky.  Light to medium body. Seems like on the finish it just cuts out from when the flavor started well.
Dark fruit notes are nice but too sweet, bland, and carbonated. Creamy. Doppelbock is not a style I go for but this is better than most since the balance of yeast, malt and hops seems about right.

Bottle. Pours brown-red with a beige head. Sweet aroma with caramel fruit and a bit of alcohol. medium-full body. Flavor is again rather sweet, with caramel, plum, cherry, and chocolate. Finishes with a light roasted note. Almost no alcohol in the flavor. Very nice.

Hazy dark brown, small white head. Aroma is sweet with a big caramel nuttiness. Flavor is the same big and sticky with lots of caramel nutty flavors, toffee, a bit of chocolate, perfumy and floral hops. Sweet and sticky with low carbonation just isnt my thing and Im not finishing this glass.
Bottle.  Probably my 3rd favorite doppelbock.  Pours dark brown with little tan head.  Aroma is chocolate, malt, nut, and spice.  A solid beer.

12oz bottle poured into a hefeweizen glass.  AM pours cola brown with a medium-sized head that sicks around for awhile.  The aroma is of nuts, not-quite-cinnamon-nor-nutmeg-spice-smell and malt.  This beer has an initial dark fruit taste that is quickly chased out by 80% hops and 20% carbonation.  Dont worry, it works.  The palate is not quite what I like.  It has a dead spot that leaves you wishing this beer had a bit less viscosity.

The bottle looks really good, the beer in the glass also. Much foam for a doppelbock. Fruity aroma. Tastes malty and fruity, for a moment a little bit bitter. Finish not too malty. Well done! Thanks to joss for the bottle!

12oz. bottle.  Plentifully malty aroma, with notes of dark caramel, toffee and black bread, sugary and showing slight hints of raisin and herbal hop.  Lightly hazy deep brown color, bottle-conditioned which is a nice touch, and a slight, fading head.  Malt easily dominates the flavor profile, showing a dark, almost burnt sugary tone throughout, becoming lightly fruity and very faintly tart, finishing with a touch of hop spice, milky toffee and some lingering dried fruit tones of raisin and date.  Smooth, full and low in effervescence on the palate with a reasonably hefty body generated by the dominant malt.  Seems pretty classy, really.  Thanks to boboski.

bottle. Smelled of yeast and malt. Poured a dark red/light brown with a brown head that went away quickly. No carbonation present at all. flavor is a bit weak for a doppelbock but not bad. flavor is sticky and malty like it says(true to what they are selling which makes me like it). Goes down nice and easy with a little bit of a bitterness to it. Another one for the non-offensive pile which is the way I like it. be careful. This says 7.5% and you really dont smell it or taste it.

Found this beer in a small German Bar in Helen, Ga.  12oz bottle, gold foil.  Pours reddish-brown, thin tan head.  Big sweet aroma of malt, caramel, honey and notes of chocolate.  Flavor is a HUGE, RICH malt, and some chocolate.  Smooth, creamy texture,  Rich and full bodied.  A very nice and enjoyable German Delicacy.  Prost!
bottle. Clear amber colour, beautiful head. Full-bodied, malty and sweet with a touch of fruit and chocolate. Also hints of caramel and toffee. Lovely!

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2010 Thanks to Ramenen. Bottle: Looking at all the ratings Ill have to re-try this one. A bit light and lacked character, boring.
Re-Rate: Great Beer!
Bottle.  Bought it at New Beer Distributors in NYC.  Sweet aroma.  Taste of caramel malts and molasses, very sweet.

Aromas of sweet malt & yeast. I can smell this from two feet away, very nice. Pours a pretty amber colour with a fluffy head that tightens up and stays put. Flavor is very different from the scent. This is a very big tasting bock. Very dry & roasty flavor light hint of rasins, coffee & chocolate. There is no doubt a presence of alcohol in this brew, but it compliments the beer well & is in no way overpowering. Very good beer.

Better than a Salvator with Easter turkey dinner.
Malt flavors that let us know a warmer spring is right around the corner.
Purchased at Beeryard in Wayne and sampled at beer appreciation class.

A Mes rate: 50cl bottle from Quinns.Clean dark brown with a slight red hue. Big off white head that eventually settles to a thin film. Lovely sweet malt aroma with some very slight coffee and some really good dark fruity notes. Big hit of alcohol in the mouth with lots more dried fruity stuff and slight herbal notes. Definite Christmas cake but in a good way (I dont care for Christmas cake...) Coffee, liquorice and some nice roasty sweet malt in the finish. An unusually complex German brew and certainly one of the best from Augustuiner.

Sampled at Boxers Cafe, Huntingdon PA: Poured a murky brown with two fingers of tan head that built nicely but disipated within a minute.  Aroma was incredibly rich with notes of caramel, sweet malt, and a hint of maple.  Flavor was the richest Ive had in a doppelbock, tons of caramel, toasty, smooth, and down right delicious.  mouthfeel is slightly sticky and the minimal carbonation fits well with the flavor.  Best doppelbock Ive tasted.

Bottle. Clear medium amber color with a small, fizzy, fair to virtually none lacing, fully diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, caramel, fruity, light alcohol. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. (150208)
(Germany) Dark Amber color with a Sm-Tan Head. Has a Spicy/Fruit Aroma with a Bitter/Malty finish. Pretty good, will try this one again.

Bottle from Johns in Iowa City. Dark amber body with a dense, medium khaki head. The aroma has some peanuts and caramel. There is also some cooked sweet potato. The taste has some almonds and light bread crust. I also get a little bit of pear core. The alcohol is well hidden in this fairly sweet beer. The carbonation is very soft in this nice example of the style.

Brown reddish brown.  Nice buy at Vintage Estates, only $1.80 for a beautifully adorned 12 oz bottle!  Nifty label when seen in person. Aroma is darkish sweet volatile olfactory, with a hint of rawness. Initially strongish with a pudding feel.  This Has a mild back of throat bite that continues to let you know this is beer. Hides the 7.5% rather well IMHO. Even tho it says hardly any carbonation in the description, this has a creamy texture to it with fine bubblies. Slight bitter maly hint but not excessive in any way. Slight alky medicinal finish.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 12 oz. bottle courtesy of alldaydrinker.  Pours a slightly hazy dark brown with ruby red highlights and a small disappearing beige head.  The aroma is sweet roasted malt with some dark fruitiness.  The flavor is rich roasted caramel malt, moderately sweet, mild fruity, and a little chocolate.  This is surprisingly good.  Full bodied, easy to drink.

Had this at the Hirschgarten, Munchen, Germany 24-01-08 This beer is served between November and April apparently according to the blurb. Poured deep reddy/brown with off white head that quickly dissipated. dark brown sugar and malt on the aroma. Taste is luscious, malty, nice dark sugars again and a soft mouthfeel, alcohol is lingering throughout. A really warming beer on a crisp Bavarian afternoon

Bottle. Poured a beautiful clear dark red body with thin head. Aroma is nice and malty, passion fruit. Flavor is well blended malt, light fruit and dried plums. Mouthfeel was spot on. So smooth and quaffable. Not only one of the best Dopplebocks Ive ever had but one of the best beers I have had in awhile.

this is a sweet and dark fruity malt brew that is sure to please (in more ways than one) good hidden and startling alcohol this beer is soft and malty with a nice sweet and cheery _as well as cherry_ taste. german wonderment.

12oz bottle, pours amber in color, not much of a head but makes up for it with a sweet malty aroma with notes of fruit and nuts. Great roasted flavor with earthy and peat like finish. truly a great Doppelbock.

Bountiful Doppelbock, this one is top notch. Sweet and nutty aroma with dense dark fruit notes. Rich amber red with a sizable light tan head and lots of spotty lacing. Medium body but exceptionally creamy and filling. Very smooth with a tantalizing sweetness and slow finish. Flavor ranges from sweet to nutty. Fruity, sugary malt with raisins and dry roasted nuts. Grapes, caramel, and some cedar. Complex and easy, this is outstanding.

12 oz. brown bottle. No freshness date seen. poured out a deep, dark smber color, with no head at all. Aromas are of stale malts, followed by cheesy hops. I dont know how old this sample is, but its well past its prime. Flavors are completely off, especially for a dopplebock. I might re-rate this if I can find a fresher sample.

What a well blanced dopple bock! Pours a nice dark brown color with amber lacing, Smells of caramel malt and chocolate. Tastes the same with hints of raisens and dark fruit. A really great pungant DB with lots of sticky terriyaki tastes and a lasting warming finish. Great beer.
Has a dark ruby color with some carbonation and a malted smell. Taste is very malted and finishes very smooth. Overall a great doppelbock.

No head and no bubbles in this caramel-dark, thick-looking brew.  Aromas of ripe pit fruit, apple, and sweet caramel.  Hefty but viscous on the tongue, with a light, drying finish.  Flavors are outstanding: cherry, plum, moss, red wine and an oaky/peaty/woodsy finish.  Special beer.  Great label is not like the one pictured at left.

From bottle, expiration date 08/2005, opened 11/2007. Brown clear body with a beige puffy head. Caramel, nuts, plum in the nose, extremely aromatic. Roasted malts and clove in mouth, with a sweet port twist at the end. Light carbonation, round and balanced. Even 2 years after expiration it remains among the great doppelbocks.

Pours dark amber with a small bubbly white head. Strong and sweet malty aroma with huge notes of fruit, caramel, and toffee. Flavor is lighter than expected, but semi-sweet and fruity. A bit of spice towards the finish, and some earthy tobacco notes. Palate is medium, slightly watery, but still has a nice mouth-feel. Balanced, flavorful, and easy drinking, but falls a bit short for a doppelbock.
Bottled. Poured amber with a dirty white head. Aroma was big and bready, with toasted notes, and caramel. Flavor was wet bread with soil/earth notes. Medium body.

Bottle (looks different than picture shown here). A dark amber brew with reddish hues on edging. A sweet smelling malty aroma with toffe, caramel and just a hint of chocolate. Flavor is similar with an easy drinking softness. Refined. Medium to full boby. An excellent smooth drinking db.

Bottle courtesy SoLan.  Sweet musky almost peay molasses aroma.  Not very peppery or spicy for a doppelbock.  Some caramel apple on the aroma also.  On the lighter side for the palate.  Sweet caramel start, some dry spice in the middle, and a mild tobacco-like finish.  Quite dry for a doppelbock.

Bottle - 355ml. Dark brown body with a thin beige frothy head. Nice, vineous malty/hoppy aroma with plummy, brown sugar and oaky hints. Awesome and perfectly balanced taste. It carries sweet and fruity notes, and ends with a good warming finish. Alcohol remains well hidden throughout the tasting experience. Although the finish could be more robust, this is a very good example of Doppelbock.

12 oz bottle.  Clear purple brown with a brief tan head.  Grapes, pastry dough and raisin.  Almost flat with a slight chocolate tang.  Smooth but a little thin.  Toffee, raisins, vinous; pretty much like the nose.  Black coffee drying.  Alcohol nicely hidden.
Bottle, though with a different label than pictured. Nice malty aroma, tan head, ruby color. Mouthfeel is a bit off... to heavy, not effervescent enough. Nice doppelbock taste with a hint of raisins.

Pours clear, brown, with a minor, fine head.
Aroma is mildly hoppy and malty. Moderate mouth feel with a strongly sweet malt flavor. Followed with a pleasant hop hit. some qualities of chocolate, smoke, and caramel fill the palate.

Bottle.  Aroma roasted malts, raisin and caramel.  Poured a brownish cola, foamy light tan head. Flavor a toffeeish mix and grassy hops, sweet with a touch raisin.  Palate was thin and watery very smooth and little carbonation.  Very interesting.

Pours a dark reddish-brown color with a medium thin and foamy beige head that dissipates rather quickly. Small patches of lacing. The aroma is roasted malt and caramel along with a touch of grassy hops. Medium-bodied with rich peaty malt  flavor coupled with plum and raisin, plus softer hops. An interesting mix overall. The finish is sweet caramel malt with earthy undertones and a lightly spiced hops aftertaste. Pretty enjoyable from start to finish.

Bottle drunk on 9/7/07Large, two-finger, light-tan head slowly recedes to cover, leaving little/no lacing.  Filtered body is a dark garnet-mahogany.Strong melanoidins provide a plethora of sweet and sour dark fruits, with aged toffee and even light molasses tartness.  Black pepper and vanillin notes are mostly tucked away but point to the filtration and pasteurization.  Chocolate and coffee practically fly out of the glass, especially as it warms, providing a very enjoyable balance to the breadiness and tart fruitiness.  If it just had a bit more yeast character (its too clean and austere, I think), without the pasteurization, it could really be special.  Medium-high strength of aroma, no alcohol noted.Shockingly flavorful and very well-attenuated, with most of the dark fruits (currants, blackberries, raisins) adding the flavor.  Chocolate and light caramel-coffee notes stem from the malt and an elegant oiliness on the palate rounds things out.  But as the aroma suffers from filtration/pasturizatoin, so does the body, being too loose/thin on the end, and without the softness/suppleness of natural carbonation.  Too bad German brewers never adopted the art of bottle conditioning, like the Belgians (though granted lagers and bottle conditioning are a whole different ballgame).

Sweet candy aroma with a hint of whisky.  Not as dark as most Doppelbocks.  The head sticks around for quite a while after pouring.  Very smooth taste, which can sneak up on you if youre not careful.  The mouthfeel is rich and deep.

Very dark amber/brown, 1.5cm frothy off white head. Aroma of dark fruits (raisins, fig, plum), toasty biscuits, and whole grains. Flavor adds some cocoa. Medium/full body, just smoother than balanced carbonation. Solid doppelbock.
(Bottle)  Pours a clear mahogany body with a small beige head.  Aroma of vinous, maple syrup, and raisins.  Flavor of raisins, molasses, and caramel malt with a somewhat sticky mouthfeel.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2007 12 oz. bottle from the Schnitz:Burnt amber pour with a firm heads that slowly fades away.  The nose is nice on this one, lots of raisins, plums and cherries are met with choclately and earthy malt.  The body is softly carbed but really drinkable.  The malt profile continues to develop, adding notes of sweet cocoa, figs, caramel, nuts and spicey alcohol.  Very nice!

Bouquet is woody, slightly smoky, with molasses, oats, hops, and peanuts present. Good aromas all, which dont necessaily come together well. Mahoghany color, opaque, with a fleeting tan head. Nutty and sweet, but yeasty. Fairly good cleansing hop finish.

What a great looking beer.  It is darker than many of its style with a medium sized tan colored head.  Not much retention.  Aroma is absolutely delicious.  Plenty of sweet malt and dark fruit aromas going on.  Just wonderful!  Flavor is very multi dimensional.  Dark chocolate, alcohol, raisins, roasted nuts and a hint of bitterness.  Very sweet but not sugary.  It tends to explode in the mouth initially then settles in with a sweet smoothness.  I could drink this beer all night.  Well, except that I would soon be under the table because of the alcohol.  But what a great beer!!  It might have entered the "Nectar Zone."

Nice offering! Poured a dark brown that hardly any light passed through with a nice fluffy head that dissipated quickly. A dark, earthy aroma leapt from the glass to tickle my nose. Tastewise, this is the most complex best balanced dopplebock Ive head. The sweet fruity taste (not sugary) was complimented fantastically with a rich coffee flavor. My favorite dopplebock to date...yes, even better than I remember the Celebrator (although maybe not quite as thick). I think this may call for a side by side "taste-off".

Now this is a good doppelbock. I dont drink these very often and its not my favorite style, but this just bursts with flavor. Pour was a flat dark ruby with no head, which kind of disappointed me. Aroma was a strong mix of malt, chocolate and alcohol. Taste was strong and syrupy...Sweet but a semi dry finish. Raisins, nuts and mostly caramel in the front with a sticky mouthfeel and little carbonation. Very nice.

text: (BBE6/07) Deep dark amber colored, little vanishing light brown head. Surprisingly lively carbonation. Rich aroma with nuts, chocolate, caramel, raisins, brown sugar, mild alcohol, some bready touch, MAN I could smell this forever! Medium to full bodied. Flavor is also rich with sweet raisins and nutty caramel, also this bready-rye touch here. Mild alcohol only in aftertaste, sweet but still biting caramelly and hopped aftertaste lasts. Maybe the best doppelbock ever for me!
Rusty brown with nice tan head.  Malty with some fruit and chocolate hints.  Thin mouthfeel and subtle carbonation.  Really nice doppelbock.

500ml bottle brought back home from Bavaria. Dark mahogany body with a rusty tint. Brown-yellow foam, gradually reduced to a skinny strip. Earthy aroma with notes of grass and peat. Rather complex in flavour; dark chocolate, late banana, dried fruit, roasted malt and, in fact, cheese all featured in a taste that does not quite take off. Dry ending with smooth alcohol (14.07.2007).
Cloudy brown body with a very little ring of white around the top. Softly carbonated and heavily malted. Slightly sweet and filled with dark fruit flavors. A very good fall beer.
Bottle 0,5l 20 Jun 07. Dark brown coloured. A small tanned head. Malty aroma with fruity hints. Malty flavor. Sweet aftertaste with a soft bitterness.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2007 Never judge a book by its colour or a beer by its appearance, ugly murky off-brown with small, short-lived head. Big malty, caramelly character, with some good subtle complexity. Extremely thin mouthfeel and dangeously easy to drink.

pours a purple/ruby color with a small tan head.  malty aroma with hints of raisin, dog food(in a good way), and burnt caramel.  flavor is malty with burnt caramel, toast, sugar coated dark fruit, and a hint of cough syrup and hops.  low carbonation.  smooth palate.  moderately chewy.  med-full bodied.

Bottle. Pours a nice clear deep amber-red colour with a good sized bubbly and creamy light brown long lastiing head. Rather thin lacing. Sweet roasty caramel and alco aroma with some dark fruits. The flavour is soft and bitter-sweet with smooth roasty caramel and malt, molasses, alcohol, some dark ruits bit chocolate, and bitter hops. The finish is sweet and dry. Served chilled. Great brew!

Pours a very dark red tinged brown with a one finger head that settles quickly to a thin soapy cap. The lacing is thin, but sticks to the glass nicely.

Smell; caramel, brown sugar and molasses are present, but theyre not overwhelming in their sweetness. Theres a bit of an alcohol presence, but it never becomes distracting, and theres almost no bitterness to speak of.

Taste; starts off a little earthy and then becomes sweet with molasses, brown sugar and some hints of dark fruits. Some toasted malts and chocolate come out in the finish, and the fruits become a bit more defined as this warms with figs and raisins.

Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with an almost syrupy texure, and relatively low carbonation. The drinkabilty, for me, is only inhinited by the alcohol content. Drinking a few of these in a row, and it tastes good enough to do just that, would get me in all kinds of trouble.
