text: On tap@ Augustiner Biergarten, Munich. Dark brown with a small beige head. Aroma is caramel. Taste is sweer and lots of caramel. Hints of alcohol. Notes of butterscotch.

Bottle. Maize in the aroma. Full bodied, bready and heavy on the tongue. Malt and raisin in the flavor. Loads of flavor! Sweet, but extremely well balanced. You really cant taste the alcohol. Hints of licorice and tropical fruit, but the malt prevails. Top class doppelbock!
Pours dark amber with a small tan head. Vinous aroma. Bready malt taste with grape flavor in addition. Alcohol completely hidden. Palate is nice, unruined by carbonation.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2007 Pours a clear dark ruby brown with a small light tan head.  Aroma is sweet fruit and vinous.  Thick chewy maple syrup malt flavor; quite buttery too.  Some hop bitterness in the aftertaste.  Not alcohol-like at all.  A worthy effort on the dopplebock front.

Bottle. Average rocky beige head that mostly diminished. Spar lacing. Clear sparkling body with a mahogany color. Heavy rye bread, fruit, caramel, roasted almost nutty aroma. Also notes of light chocolate, raisin and prune. Full bodied with a flat carbonation and a light sticky texture and a hint of alcohol as well. Flavor was heavy sweet caramel with light notes of bitter roasted malt. Lingering rye bread like finish. Quit nice Doppelbock. More of that please.

A thick, malty, tasty beer. Thoroughly enjoyable. Dark cooper/burgandy pour with small, off-white head. Nice aroma of sweet malts with notes of caramel and molasses and fruit, prune and fig. Some earthy notes as well. The flavor is mostly sweet with only a slight bitterness. The body if full and leaves a welcome sticky mouthfeel. Very little carbonation. Excellent.

Bottle - Dark orange, little head, cherry-cinnamon aroma.   True when they say "Sticky" a coffee/malt flavour with a toffee finish, the alcohol is present but not overpowering. The more I sup at it, the nicer and easier it is to drink. Upon resmelling, I now smell candyfloss (?!!) NICE

Pours an darkish amber; Aroma is sweet with caramel malt and dark fruit.  Flavor is sweet and alot of caramel; also a pretty strong dark fruit presence.  Nice mouthfeel; a little sticky.  Very easy to drink.
A great reddish amber color although there really much of a head.  Very heavy carmel taste but almost like eating candy.a very nice brew

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2007 Bottles same as 2nd one pictured.  Luscious, lick your lip looking liquid lathered lovingly within my lucky mug.  Big sweet heavy malt doppelbock aroma hits you with every sip all the way to the finish.  Hearty rich flavor of caramel, malt and sweet dried fruits.  Mouthfeel is full bodied and sticky to the tongue.  Alcohol is hidden well.  However, it provided a kick stronger than 7.5% listed ABV.  A lingering caramelized aftertaste that is reminiscent of a fine brandy allows plenty of enjoyment between sips.  Very nice.  I will drink this again.

Bottle. Light brown fluffy but lasting head. Beautiful clear ruby body. Sweet malt aroma with notes of berries. Sweet and sugary malt flavor with caramel cocoa berries notes. Low carbonation, little bitternes and short aftertaste.

It has a nice sticky malty overtone with a fuzzy head, sugary aroma and somewhat creamy but light mouthfeel. Its a pleasure to drink this if you like doppelbocks. Im okay with them. I think this one is a bit too sticky for me and a bit too sweet.

12 oz bottle, looks just like the 2nd pic you see when you click the picture. Pours a dark, clear reddish amber topped by a thin beige head. Sweet caramel and dark brown sugar nose, earthy light molasses. Sweet and malty flavors, roasty with a peppery dash. Thick, soft, somewhat sticky mouthfeel - downright chewy. Alcohol finally pops up in the gullet. Nice doppel!
mas krug draft - wow.  Pours dark brown wwhitish head.  Lots of caramel malty flavor but not too sweet.  Really excellent.
12 oz bottle. Pours brown in color with brown head. Sweat aroma. Taste of caramel and coffee bitter after taste.

clear dark amber brown with a nice disappearing tan head. nice banana fostersish aroma. caramel brown sugar bananas. sweet caramel light chocolate flavor a bit of raison nice light bitter balance. sweet but slightly dry chocolate raison finish with a light alcohol presence. tart raison sticks with you for quite a while.   medium full body. nice beer.

From a 12 ozer, this produced a nice falling pour, seemlingly still at first, but slowly and surely creating a nice carbonated rise into a firm, but very thin head of foam.  The body is deep crimson with a steady amount of carbonation continuing to boil.  The aroma accosts my nasal passages with an alcoholic sting ... and an almost cherry-juice aspect.  At the first sip, that hint of cherry rears its head again, although subtle and restrained, like a mildly flavored cough drop.  That sliver of the flavor settles into the background as I go ... and this mellows into a very drinkable and smooth caramel-laden, warming brew.  All the way nice.  (#2734, 3/5/2007)

Pours copperish brown with some reddish hues and an off white head.  The aroma is malty with caramel and dark fruit.  Nice and malty flavor with caramel, roasted malt, and some dark fruit.  Finsihes with a touch of roasted malt on the palate.
Thanks to Hopscotch.  12 ounce bottle.  Brownish red.  Oxidized malt nose.  Rich mouthfeel.  Fairly nice flavor.

Bottle from Degarth, Thanks Joe! Nose of caramel, fig newtons, and sweetness; lightly hazed dark brown with a small beige head;  flavor is molassey, with dark fruits, and roasty graininess. Decent dopplebock.
Thin head, but good color.  Aroma is interesting, almost a hoisin sauce character to it.  Very rich flavor, like dried fruits and dark caramel.

dark brown pour small whispy tan head.  Aroma is full of dark fruits plum and carmel some fig as well some toasty grainy notes as well.  Pal is pretty small, but not to bad.  The flavor is rich and fruity lots of plum and some fig tiny hints of carmel a bit of weak syrups, ok at best.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2007 Very dark brown pour, translucent, with orange and red hues strewn about. mostly diminishing beige head leaves fat bubbles at the edges. This looks exactly like it should, now Im excited. Aroma is lightly roasted caramel malts, molasses, grains. The nose is subtle but enjoyable, I do wish though that it were more forthcoming, I still dont know what to expect from the flavor, excitement is dwindling. Heavily toasted grains lead in the flavor, followed quickly by bold, fresh caramel and subtle grassiness. Not quite what Id hoped for. Too much Celebrator, perhaps? That said, this is a very complex feeling beer that just doesnt open up enough to be thoroughly enjoyed and explored. Finishes with long-lingering sweet caramel. Palate is medium and syrupy, bordering on cloying. Very quaffable Dopplebock but rather unexciting.

Pours a dark maroon with a very light tan head.  Very sweet malts, molasses, raisins and caramel in the smell typical of doppelbocks.  Alot of dark fruit, caramle, and swet malts in the taste that are balanced pretty well.  Just a pretty damn good doppelbock, very similar to many Ive had before.  Nothing that makes it stand out but solid nonetheless.

Aroma smells of prunes, raisons and plums with a very citrus floral scent.  There is also a mild aroma and smell of licorice.  The appearance is a deep dark brown porter appearance with moderate to light head an very little lacing.  The palate is moderately complex with a nice hint of alcohol.  This beer is a strong evening beer that goes fantastic with a nice porterhouse steak.

Gold foil capped 12 oz bottle from Joe Canals in West Deptford, NJ. The aroma is sweet dark malts that render a dark baked bread aroma that is at once hearty and sweet with fruit and mild raisina nd molasses notes. Pumpernickel soaked in a raisin and molasses mash comes to mind. It smells quite nice. The body is a dark ruby brown color and holds a diminishing tan head that is a thumb thick and quite creamy looking before fading.

Raisins, carmelized malt, rum soaked sweet dark bread, baked apples and some mild roast bitterness in the finish. Has a slightly sticky mouthfeel. This is quite good and Im happy I got more than just one bottle.

From a slender 12 oz. gold foiled wrapped narrow neck bottle with no freshness date.

Poured a reddish hued cola brown with a small foamy head that settled into a thin lacing.

Aromas of sweet caramelized malts with a raisin fruitiness, spicy hops that meshes with the alcohol.

Good moderate carbonation and a crisp, creamy medium bodied mouthfeel.

Pleasant, but overall, slightly above average doppelbock taste, sweet caramelized and toffee malts, a dark raisin fruitiness, a subtle grainy maltiness,  a soft spicy hoppiness, towards the end, a fusel alcohol flavor emerges, and a dry, sweet malty, fruity finish.
dark brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma is sweet and malty with a hint of bananna.  Taste is the same, but less potent (a bit of a let-down). $2.50/12oz
Very rich with weight on the tongue and many complex flavors. Better luke cold.

Lucky to grab a bottle of this during World Cup @ Augustiner Bräu, München, Germany.  Shared with new-found backpacker friends,  I found I only got slops on what was said to be one of the last bottles. Mention alcohol percentage in a beer and suddenly you are swarmed by youthful tourists pretending to be your longtime mates - well not really, Im just a generous bugger. Into a pilsner flute. Poured a deep copper brown, quite bright , with a tidy pad of white forming, but later dying of to nothing (glass was second-use). Heady, poignant, sticky-date pudding and peat-malt nose with a claspy, nutty edge that didnt at all aid to swerve from its dessert-like aromatics. Surprisingly, the alcohol tickles and doesnt hide. Rum, raisin and hefty malts. 
 Sticky, heavy palate that acts like a liqueur up against the lagers of the day. Its syrupy and smooth, a good level of sweetest toffee, tangy orange-peels,  burnt fruit, and a rasp of vine-clippings work to make it pleasurable.  The finish is savoury, fruity and does harness that odd, catching phrase in a word - Melanoiden. This is nice, though my sample disappeared quickly into other peoples mouths. Augustiner still invokes that true spirit of Bayern. Lovely stuff!!!!
11/11/06: Bottle.  Sweet nutty aroma.  Dark, red-brown body.  Medium head which diminishes quickly.  No lace.  Flavor is roasted, malty and bitter.  Finish is sour and medium long.
Dark red color, thin head of tight bubbles. Aroma is very rich and earthy malt. Flavor is rich, well blended, and smooth. Candy and smoke mixed together. Very nice.

Pours deep mahogany into a stem glass.  Head quickly subsides to skim rim.  Fruity roasted malt aromas.  Dry and crisp with front to back sweet sticky smoked malt. Dry and sticky? Yep.  Medium lasting prune finish.

Pours a deep brown with a ruby hue, almost no head. The aroma is malty, sweet, yet a bitter fruit juice aspect comes out, with a touch of soysauce like scents. The body is thick and viscous. Huge chewy maltyness. Theres a soysauce, salty aspect, yet a sweet butterscotch background. The finish is long and roasty.

Rich deep clear copper with a bubbly head. Aroma of toffee, alcohol, brown sugar, apricot jam, and yeast... very sweet and sticky. The body is very rich also, with flavours of toffee, biscuit, yeast and some strong spicy hops. The finish is bitter and very caramely sweet, this lasts quite a long time. Enjoyable!

Dark brown body with tan foam.  Head wears off quickly.  Beer itself is fizzy; you can feel the carbonation as an integral part of this beers overall appeal.  Has a roasty, earthy taste, slightly bitter.  A good beer for a chilly fall day.

Beautiful dark red-brown beer with a purple shine; smallish dark yellow creamy head, fast gone. Bready, molasses, bit of licorice, cassis and plums in the nose. Bitterish, very roasted taste upon a truckload of mixed malts (chocolate/roasted/pale/Münich,...) bit metallic ending. Titillating, CO² impression MF, with medium to well-bodied, finish is, again, empty. Nose promises a lot, but the finish is really empty. Im afraid this has been a way more complex beer, once. At least, its not too sweet.

Pour is dark brown with a minimal head that dissipates without leaving much evidence behind.  Aromas are roasty, a little smokey/peaty and fruity.  The first thing that hit me is that this has a much thicker mouthfeel than I expected.  Almost syrupy.  Flavor is also fruitier than I thought... when I first opened the bottle the aroma was almost entirely of dried fruit, but after a minute or so it became much more dark malt based... with the prune-like scents taking the backseat.  Im also picking up a slight hint of molasses and a bit of sweet stickiness.  Well blended and nicely covers the 7.5% ABV...
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: The 12 ounce bottle was bottle conditioned and poured a hazy, reddish brown beverage with a small thick off-white head that was mostly diminishing but left some lacing on the glass. The aroma was complex consisting of pungent dried fruits (plum and raisin) with a subtle hint of molasses and earth in the background. The body was very full with soft carbonation and a thick, sticky texture. The flavor started off with a medium sweetness that lasted throughout the long finish. There was a nice alcohol warmth that built toward the end as well.

Bottle, Chef Pauls Bavarian Lodge in Lisle, IL.  Enjoyed as desert after a tasty Rouladen I was surprised and impressed with this Doppel!  It poured into the dimpled mug a very dark brown with some ruby highlights and was crested with a smallish tan head that would leave a little lacing.  A sweet aroma of brown sugar in this very malty brew.  Some sweet gruit was also detectable as it warmed up.  Taste was very sweet upfront, but pleasantly so.  It developed into a satisfying body of malt that had a nutty richness to it and was countered by just a touch of biterness before finishing smooth and exceptionally rich with a playful tingle on the tongue.  This was exceptional!

Bottle (from Bitter Virtue, BB Aug 06). Deep mahogany brown. Light roast, caramel, molasses, liquorice, bready malts, earthy hop and subtle fruits in the complex nose. Liquorice and smooth roast is dominant which is fine by me. Flavours continue into the fairly sweet body which is tempered by smooth bitterness in the finish. Not too sweet and uses its strength to good effect. Considerably better than its namesake Amsterdam Maximator!
50 cl bottle from a friend. Red-brown color, tan head. Sweet heavy malty scent. Sweet taste. Low bitterness. Medium mouthfeel.

Bottle. Weak, yeasty, roasted aroma. Clear dark brown colour. Light brown head. Looks a lot like cola. Very powerful liquorice flavour, a bit sweet with a good alcohol bite and a nice creamy finish. Hint of metal. A bit one-dimensional and not as good as expected.

Brown color; big head, not compact. Malt aroma. It has some malt flavor, some caramel, a light metallic touch, medium body strength, enough residual sugars; at the end there is some sweetness and liquorice. Regular.

Bottle, purchased at Cairo Liquor, Washington DC.  Dark woody brown colored body, with a short-lived head the color of browned toast.  Nose is precisely dopperbock: sweet, almost fruity malt body, light alcohol, light butter, light char, full of sweet chocolate scents.  Flavor is similar, with a clean palate, sweet all around.  Good nutty almond and chocolate flavors, light butter (or even vanilla).  Good stuff.

Beautifully comforting nose of caramel, toffee, maple syrup and brown sugar.  Pours dark ruby brown with a medium head, light retention and sudsy lacing.  Caramel and toffee malt flavors, mixed with dried dark fruits (raisins and prunes), along with an almond-ine back palate.  These flavors are well-integrated with dates and figs.  All of these flavors are quite complimentary to the bouquet.  The finish is somewhat toffee-esque, not cloying, with a tiny bit of astringency.  Very complex dark sweet brew, and quite comforting.  As Korb would say: "Oh, how I do like the Maximator...."

Thick, rich and enticingly creamy aroma of strong malts and caramel.  Quite nice-looking too, with a dark reddish-brown body and a small off-white head.  There are prunes in the flavor, as well as a hint of figs (which I love).  Lactose sweetness is evident,. but it is not too syrupy or overly sweet at all.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Very complex body: a nice gentle woodiness blends well with the nuttiness.  A pleasant, earthy doppelbock - it is interesing and good.

Thanks to weeare138.  Indigo-brown body with a collapsing pale tan head. Aroma has nice aged malt qualities with balsamic notes plus some prune. Flavor is nutty and slightly madeirized with sweet and open medium dark German malts and some balancing dark fruit acidity. A good, mature doppelbock.

Black cherry appearance with a small head.  Molassas, maple sugar, cinnamon and dark fruit evolve from the sweet malt aroma.  Full bodied, modestly carbonated mouthfeel.  Tastes vary from a range of dark fruits such as prunes and figs to the sweetness associated with brown sugar and molassas.  Thick, cloying, long lasting finish.

Appears a muddled dark brown with caramel reddish edges. A light tan head fades into a mild film with a heavy collar settling into the sides. Small streakes of lacing are left around the glass.
Smell is of heavy weighted malt with cocoa and rich syrup. Mild oxidation can be sensed in the background.
Taste is of the same aromas with the malty richness and cocoa notes.
Mouthfeel contains little bits of syrupy malt but its a tad thin along the palate. Overall, not bad considering we dont know the age of it. This was bought at Michaels Deli in KOP.

Thanks to weeare138.  Pours a dark brown with some golden coming through.  Small off white head.  Aroma of molasses, caramel, dark fruits, sweet malts and some roast.  Flavors of the same, smooth mouthfeel, slight alcohol presence.  More of the malty, dark fruit thing going on. Really enjoyed trying this one.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2016 Bottle.  Ruby brown with a light brown, violent head.  Smells sweetly and heavily of malt.  Other notes include caramel, chocolate, brown sugar, a little dark roasted malt, and notes of grape and berries.  Tastes the same but much stronger, huge dose of malt and a mouth-filling feel, sticky and thick.  Malt is thick enough to pose danger of choking.  Earthy. Molasses and raisins.  A bit of alcohol, but a thin bit.  Ah, wait, theres cherry here, too.  Very smooth, no carbonation or crispness here.  Dry end with medium bitterness.  Well-balanced and complex - a fantastic Doppelbock.  Thanks, joss! [2006.07.02: 4.2]
Smaller 330ml bottle dragged back from Vintage Estate, and Im chuffed at the find.  Nose is throwing out huge dark, deep, earthy caramel form the neck, and its even better in the glass after some agitation.  Beautiful deep ruby-mahogany body with a short tan head.  Mmmm, rich, Munich-heavy, dense malt is just incredible (and relatively dry, which threatens to induce a fainting spell!), recalling the gooiest of candy bar chocolate, caramel, nougat stretching from wrapper to teeth, but without the sugar.  In this one, the fruit is late-arriving and less of a star, though the cherry, red berry, and grape are all high-quality and sparkle in their own right.  No, its the thick malt, with molasses, raisin, perhaps a touch of mild rum, that shines more than any other time Ive had this, syrupy and filling with pump crusts, just a light prickle of sufficient carbonation and milder lemon to take the edge off.  Have had thousands of beers in between but never expected this kind of reunion!  [2016.07.30: 4.8]

Bottle - Pours thick dark brown with thin tan head and good lacing.  Aroma is roasty malt and bread with some sweetness.  Palate is medium in body, oily, smooth and long lasting.  Taste is somewhat sweet and malty with some raisin notes.  No bitterness to speak of.  Lasting aftertaste with a touch of caramel sweetness, some bready notes and a hint of alcohol warming.  This one really coats the mouth and sticks with you for a bit.  Overall a great doppelbock.

Brown body with a beautiful red shine, light brown creamy head disappearing quite fast leaving some laces; A quite fresh nose that almost tickles of carbonation, sweet tangerine, it opens with time and becomes more mellow: roasted malt, sweet soft milk chocolate, some cinnamon and overripe fresh fig; Sweet, soft, creamy velvety body, dry carbonation; Into quite dry long finish that has a very little metallic to it and not a lot of aroma: creamy honey, warm spices like allspice and some late sweet licorice.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2006 A very nice doppelbock. Poured a dark red-brown color with a nice but not too big tan head. Lacing was minimal. Aroma was musty and malty, somewhat sweet vinous with some dark fruits coming through. The most surprising feature of the flavor was the nutty taste that came through, almost like a nut brown doppelbock (I was expecting some coffee - although I didnt detect any in the aroma - per word from my good friend, doulos). This didnt have enough hop balance or as creamy a mouthfeel to take out Ayingers Celebrator as #1 Doppel, but it was very nice anyway. Re-rate, Sept. 06: Deep burgundy brown color with a slow developing tan head. Little chocolate, grassy hops, and some dark fruits (figs and raisins). The flavor was like the aroma, decent hop balance, although more malty than hoppy. Not too sweet, though, a very competent doppelbock, which does well among the best (vs. Celebrator, Andechser, Liberator).

(bottle) Clear, dark reddish-amber colour with a beige foamy medium head. Aromatic sweet and toasty malt aroma with a fruity background (dark berries, grapes). Moderately sweet flavour, medium to full bodied, medium carbonation. Strong toast-malty taste with molasses, a touch of caramel and raisins; dryer and slightly bitter towards the end with a malty and long lasting finish. Superb ! Many thanks to Joss for this gem.

This dopplebock pours a deep brown color from a 12oz bottle. Small sized white foamy head. Aroma is caramel, bread and brown sugar. A medium bodied dopple. Malts are caramel and sweet. Some cherries, some dark bread and some chocolate flavors. Kind of earthy, Not a lot of carbonation. Very smooth tasting. Perhaps a little watery and flat, but that might be due to the lack of carbonation. All in all not bad. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

Pours a deep amber with a small, light tan head. The aroma is caramel and toffee, some nuttiness. The flavor is rich, sweet, caramel, molases, chocolates, roasted and prunes. Medium body, with a lightly bitter finish amd lively carbonation.

Bottle. Dark reddish brown pour with an average creamy off-white head that diminished slowly. Solid sweet dark fruit aroma. Medium to full body with a sticky texture. Soild sweet prune flavor with a malty finish of long duration. Complex brew with no alcohol bite.

Bottle (thank You very much,joss !) Reddish-amber coloured, mid-sized fluffy off-white head, slowly diminishing; quite strong fruity nose(...berries, nuts) mixed with molasses, sweet malt (and a touch of cinnamon?); mainly sweetish, but also bitter flavour; quite long first sweetish fruity and malty finish; becoming dryer and a bit chocolatey. Full bodied, but well drinkable, though. A pleasure....................!
Deep mohogany color with a thin creamy light brown head. Dark malt aroma. Flavor of sweet molassas.
Draught at Augustiner bräu. Brownish colour with a light brown fully lasting head. Powerful aroma and taste of malts and fruits. Great beer.

Draught. Fantastic beer. Perfect appearence. Creamy excellent fully lasting head. Redbrown colour.Powerfull aroma with strong notes of sloe-berries. Fantastic complex flavor and very long finish. Oily palate.
Pours a dark red with a tanned head. Very sweet and quite breadlike. Portish, dry finish.

Sampler from bottle. Big and rich malt flavor with light chocolate notes to it. A nice change to an authentic doppel after sampling a Leinies Big Butt. This one has a deep brown color, and finishes very hearty. This is the kind of beer thats conjured to mind when reading about the brews those monks drank to get through Lenten fasting.
Red-black body with a light white head.  Coffee and peet dominate the aroma with sweets and honey to compliment.  Excellent taste based on caramel and suggar.  Very clean ending.

Dough, brown sugar, dark fruit in the nose.  Murky orange-brown stuff with a thin head.  Big malty palate with a bit of alcohol there and some grainy notes.  Finishes with a grainy-sour feel.  Nice experience.
"I love doppelbocks. Poured a brown color with a nice head, with not much lacing. Aroma was malty, and of dark fruits. Mouthfeel was a little bit creamy. Very good beer. "

Chocolatey aroma, light turd brown in color, head is off-white but there isnt much and what ther is doesnt stick around for too long.  Wonderful malty chocolate/heavy fruit flavor.  Finishes nice, just enough bittering hops to balance the huge maltiness.  Awesome beer.  Thanks Roger.

Augustiner Maximator pours to a deep, bright, chestnut brown color with a creamy off white head, and a moderate carbonation. The nose on this beer is stunning. Deep, toasty, sweet malty, and nutty waves of aroma flood the nose. The palate is hefty, and chewy with big sweet malty flavors paired with more toasty and nutty character. This beer ends with more big malt up front, then is balanced with just enough hop presence so this beer isnt cloying. This is paired with a high octane, soothing, warming burn. 

Without a doubt one of the finest examples of dopple bock on the market today, and a true bench mark for this style. This beer is hard to find, but if you are lucky enough to find it here in America, snap it up, and as much as you can. Dopple bocks are rich, strong brews that will stand up to some age. You wont be able to put too much age on it, as you will want to drink it. This beer is suited more for the colder months, but makes the perfect night cap, and would work well with deserts. I would pair this one with creme brulee, but would much rather enjoy this beer by itself. This beer truly is a "mash tun in a glass", an is a flawless example of dopple bock. I cant not praise this beer enough.

This beer pours a silky dark brown and leaves a sticky beige head that lingers in the glass. As I smell this beer I can really get the caramal a faint alcohol smell as well as the chocolate and a dark fruit essence. The taste is slightly sweet with a def bitter chocolate malty presence and a finish of hops and alcohal. I can also feel a sense of warmth as this beer flows down the throat. This is a decent brew that has a great finish and is pretty balanced. Although could be better for the style and price.

Bottled. 
Dark brown colour. Light brown head. Wonderful chocolatey tone in aroma. Vineous backbone with bitter chocolate in the finish. Very very flavourful!

500ml bottle: Im surprised to see that this beer has so many ratings. Purchased in Germany. Nice aroma of bubblegum, soy sauce, dark fruits. Medium sized beige head. Rich malty flavor with some soy sauce, lots of chocolate, raisins, plums. A cornucopia of flavor here. The finish is lightly bitter and fairly quick. This is a damn good beer. My wife even likes it. I wonder why it took me so long to drink it. Its been in my fridge for over a month.

Pours dark amber with a mostly receding tan head. Aroma of sweet caramelized wort, raisins, plums, toffee, and gingerbread. The taste highlights the spectrum of kiln treated malts, from the lightly toasted crystal to the roasted chocolate. Mouthfeel is heavy and slighty sticky with lush carbonation. The innermingling layers of malt create a sticky vinous quality that makes this a truly unique beer. This beer is a suitable replacement for bread.

Dark ruby-brown with small dark tan head, leaves some lace.  Sweet nose, strong grapes, lesser fruits, molasses, brown sugar, malt.  Flavor is outstanding -- toasty sweet malt, bready yeast, hop bitterness but little hop flavor.  Thick and chewy.  A malt-lovers delight.

Hard to find a sweeter, chewier, more malty beer than this.  Pours a small tan head over a walnut hued beer.  Perfect carbonation that freely emits tiny bubbles with each sip.  Aroma is strong with molasses, caramel and toffee.  Hits all over the mouth with bitterness, sweetness, and some smokey notes.  The overriding flavor is caramel and roasted nuts..like a turtle candy, with a kick of alcoholic warmth.  No one does this style better.

A deep, thick burgundy/copper under a creamy, tan head. Aroma is caramely sweet with plenty of dark fruit and fruity esters. A hearty bock with a boatload of malts & a nice alcohol-kick. There was an attempt at balance with some bittering hops, but they almost went unnoticed. The only problem I found was a thick, sour film that was left on my throat afterwards.

50cl bottle. Date on the bottle is 04 05. Served at 52.5°F/ 11.5°C in a 22oz lager glass. Pours dark crimson, nearly brown, with a very small off white head, really just more of a bubble ring. Aroma is dark fruit such as  plums, raisins, prunes, and dark brown sugar. There is also an earthiness, spiciness hiding underneath. The taste is caramel, toffee, milk chocolate, with ripe dark fruit and some more of the earthiness/spiciness from the aroma. The finish is warming alcohol, mild bitterness, and  palate cleansing astringency. Nice thick mouthfeel. Pretty good stuff. Thanks go to Nat for this beer, it came all the way from Hamburg.
12 oz bottle.  Poured a deep brown with a thin tan head with great lacing.  Very heavy aroma of dark caramel and malts.  Huge on your palate, but with a sweet finish.  A good dopplebock.
Sampled at RBESG 2005. Brown colour. Little malty aroma. Big mouthfeel with a malty taste that ends bitter and hoppy.

Bottle: Dark brown, burnt caramel edges, moderate light beige head, foamy, fairly nice lacing. &nbsp Rich bready nose, heavy, with notes of dried dark fruit. &nbsp Sweet malt on the tongue, bready, very smooth and clean. &nbsp Not much soy in this, which I like. &nbsp Soft dried dark fruit, perhaps a touch of brown sugar and/or molasses. &nbsp Big body, fairly moderate mouthfeel. &nbsp Clean finish, lingering malty sweetness. &nbsp Great stuff. &nbsp Thanks for the freebie Jeff!
RBESG 2005, Deep copper colour with a fast disappearing off white head. Fruity sweet aroma with a clear alcohol note. Sweet flavor with raisin and caramel notes and a light alcohol finish.
Bottle. Brown color with a off white head. The taste is a sweet caramel body with a rather thin palate.
nice reddish colour.  KInda thick like oil, but pretty good.  Big head also.  Pretty enjoyable brew.

Good looking Doppelbock, dark brown that raises a thick head of toffee that coats the glass with lace as it slowly eases back.
Rich aroma of dark caramel and raisins.
Could be a bit heavier bodied, but overall this is a decent Doppel.
Pours brown with a one-finger tan head. Aroma of toffee, plum, and sweet, sweet sugar. Flavor of caramel, roasted malts, toffee, and brown sugar. Very sweet. Good.
UPDATED: SEP 12, 2005 Bottled at RBESG. Mid brown. Sweet, roasty and full bodied. Warming with generous malt flavours and soft moutfheel. Some butterscotch and coffee, salty finish. Very tasty!
Bottle. Brown colour with a baige head. Sweet caramel malty prun aroma and taste. Medium body and a sweet finish.

Pours brown, with a tan head. Aromas are sweet malt, some dark fruit,and sugar. Flavor is very sweet malt, brown sugar, dark fruit, and maybe even some chocolate. Not bad, but with the sweetness, its would never be an everyday brew.

(Bottle 50 cl) Dark, clear amber colour with a beige head. Lots of caramel in the nose. Surprisingly light body considering the alcohol. Distinct notes of roasted malt and caramel. Very easygoing Doppelbock. 120805

Bottled at RBESG 2005.
Brown coloured with a yellow head.
Sweet aroma of bread, caramel and dried fruits.
Very sweet flavour of malts, bread and caramel.
Bottle RBESG. Fresh, hoppy aroma. Flavor is mostly metallic. Malty metallic. Aftertaste is burnt sugar. With some metal.
Beautiful roasty nose and smooth, smooth sticky taste.  Its just a bit thin on the aftertaste, but this is a very nice beer.  Very little carbonation and just like a handpulled beer.  Nicely done.

330 ml bottle.  Deep dark brown beer.  Beautiful toasted nut aroma, complex caramel, toffee, brown sugar.  Slightly earthy aroma with a lot of sweet syrupy malt character.  Sweet caramel flavour, nice creamy body with a long toasty finish.  A touch of pepper and very faint bitterness.

Dark brown w/ frothy, light brown foam. Sweet, slightly roasty aroma of caramel, brown sugar, licorice & chocolate.  Creamy, medium feel. Flavour is sweet & earthy w/ a mild sourness. Sweet finish w/ notes of alcohol.

Licorice and anise and grassy aroma. Very dark brown, carmel coca-cola and well carbonated, large but dissapearing head, lace, sourness like a Baltic. cocoa powder in medium mouthfeel. Mixed up well with different other tastes, more of a cooking beer by itself.

Bottle.  New Label.  Sweet, sticky malty aroma with mild vinousness in the aroma.  Some nuttiness and some oxidized caramelly aromas.  Transparent garnet color with a light tan head.  Start is mildly sweet, turning roasy and very smooth with lots of caramel malts.  Sweet notes, and a bit toastiness.  This is seductively smooth and very drinkable.  A great beer that should be rated higher.

Bottle.  Label is different than that in the picture.  I wouldnt be surprised if this is a pretty old bottle since it came from Chevy Chase Liquors in DC where they apparently hold onto their stock until it sells.  A near-opaque, DEEP, DEEP mahogany pour with a thin khaki head.  Aroma is of molasses, coffee, dark chocolate, anise and wheat bread.  Carbonation is a little high.  Rich and thick.  A good bit of chocolate, coffee and molasses in the taste.  Starts off with some sweet malts that exude a little chocolate-covered raisin quality.  Some bitter hops make a token appearance at the end.  The slightest bit of warming alcohol is present in the finish.  An excellent full-bodied beer.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2007 Pours muddy red with a quickly-dissipating head with a malty raisin aroma. Tastes of earthy molasses, light floral hops and notes of coffee and dark chocolate that make this a perfect after-dinner treat.  Satisfying alcohol esters in the finish. Hops become more pronounced with warming. The Al Green of Doppelbocks.

UPDATED: APR 24, 2009 Bottle.  Rich molasses malt aroma - mild tannins.   A dark brown / blood red color with negligible head.  Thick molasses malt flavor - moderate hops bitterness and astrigency.  Very nice body.  This is a nice easy drinking doppelbock but may not be strong enough for some.

One of the fine German Doppelbocks but this one is different in the fact that it has almost no discernible hop bitterness which, to me, throws it out of balance. Combine that with minimal carbonation and you got yourself a flavorful beer syrup. Its too sweet also. Not my favorite of style but great for some tastes.

Popped off the cap and boom! - here comes the foam.  Got it in the .5 L boot as quickly as possible.  Color is a deep, dark brown with caramel and ruby accent hues around the cusps.  My, my, my.  Foamy, booming 1" head slowly fizzles down.  Wondrously rich caramel aroma, caramelized pecans and sugar brazed walnuts.  Some discernable smells of milk chocolate, hints of peat and a touch of rye pretzel bread.  Flavor is smooth chocolate and caramel, rolling over the palate like a Rolo.  Subtle golden delicious apple-like sweetening that transitions to more substantive figs and prunes.  Nails the "liquid bread" parameter, as it matches fresh pumpernickel bread flavoring.  Welcome to the Maximators Malt Clinic, please take a seat.  Very smooth on the palate with nearly no carbonation, some most likely lost in the initial foam boom.  No cloying sweetness or stickyness.  Flavor slips away gradually and fades into the background.  Tiny tingling at the back of the throat hints at the moderate ABV.  Finishes like tiramisu.  Solid doppelbock.

In the 500 ml bottle at the Huber Haus. Dark pour with a tan head. Dominant molasses aroma with straw or hay tossed in for good measure. Glucose tolerance test sweet, but hop strong for a deliciously smooth balance. I think I like it better than Spaten or Paulaner doppels, so once again, the little guy in Munich rules the roost.

a huge whiff of caramel aroma w/ hint of toffee. the head subsides quickly, full bodied.  the taste is full of malt, sweet and chocolaty.  no significant trace of hops, as is usual w/ this type of beer.  maybe not as good as celebrator, but definitely a worthy dopplebock.

(on bottle; superpowermax-thanx to joss for this baby)Dark ruby red with a shortlsting, toffee-cloured head. A strange carbonation; perfect, but perls on throughout the drink.Rum, dade and loads of ageing is what I smelled, namnam. Watery mouth and a joyfull tart, burnt finish, allmost coffee-like. Has no cloying cane-sugarness like 90% of these DBs.

Bottle... Very dark, ruby lager with a well-tanned head. Malty aroma displays notes of molasses, brown sugar, and light soy sauce. Thick, hearty body with flavors of very light molasses, dried plum, caramelized brown sugar and lightly bitter, citrusy hops. Full-bodied and oily with lively carbonation. The finish is full of dark fruit, bitter-sweet chocolate and drying, astringent alcohol.

This beer is all about malt and alcohol.  Dark brown with ruby hightlights, theres little carbonation and  a tiny wisp of a head that vanishes immediately.  Its got a sweet malt aroma with traces of dark, juicy fruits and a definite alcohol presence.  Its sticky sweet to drink, malt with raisins and molasses and a hardy, warming alcohol taste.  Nice doppelbock.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2009 Bottled.  A rich ruby coloured beer.  The aroma is full, fruity, jammy and vinuous.  There are notes of raisins, licquorice and wood.  The taste is thick and full bodied.  Nice alcohol notes, more raisin fruits and licquorice and a real warming mouthfeel.  Another top quality Doppelbock akin to the Ayinger, Andechser and Weltenberger.Score 4.3Subsequent rating scored 3.9. Average becomes 4.1

The bottle I had looks very different then the one in the picture.  I hope this is the correct beer.  Nice caramel aroma with raisin, chocolate and coffee in it as well.  The taste is basically the same as that except for the cherry that I did not get in the aroma.  There was also an intense wine mouthfeel which was very effective.  I really liked this Doppelbock.
Poured a dark ruby red with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of bread, dark fruits and molasses. Tastes of brown sugar, dark fruits and molasses. Malty. Light alcohol in the finish.

Sweet caramelly nose with hints of molasses and cherry, deep clear mahogany color, low frothy head that clings to the sides. Molasses again in the taste with some berry (black cherry). Nutty-ish in the middle. Light coffee flavor creeped in too. Drying oaky bitter towards edn. Medium body. Brandy-like feeling from the alcohol as it goes down. Classy and sophisticated big beer.

What a Easter wonder to find this Bavarian Brew in Hamburg - really! Nice medium egg shell white , fast diminishing head. Nearly opaque black color. Light alcohol and bandaid nose but nice. An intense molasses taste with some light malt and toffee notes. Medium long lasting. Smooth all in all. Nice one!
Fairly dark brown. Malty aroma with brown sugar and raisins. A chewey, sticky body. Flavor is sweet with some raisins too and a touch of alcohol. Not crazy about this beer, but i cant complain.

Bottle:  Lots of brown sugar and fruit in the aroma.  Pours a mostly transparent reddish-brown with an off-white head that is short lasting.  Flavor is very malty.  Fruit, brown sugar, molasses, and caramel.   Chocolate and some extra sweetness show up in the finish.

Deep red copper with a brown viscous consistence and light brown head. Rich sweet malt aroma with light citrus and vanilla. Deep rich sugar licorice with an oily mouthfeel. Rich bodied and satisfying. Jan 2005.

Bottled. Dark ruby red colour. Vivid, bubbly and quickly diminishing head. Malty, caramelly aroma with notes of chocolate and hints of floral hops. Malty, slightly chocolatey, sweet and bitter taste. Molasses, raisins. Bitter-chocolatey finish, which is quite lasting. Medium- to fullbodied, with a somewhat thick texture. At first, it comes off as astoundingly bitter for a doppelbock, but as it warms it regains the classic doppelbock flavour. A very nice flavour in this one, that is. Not too sweet, and a really good mouthfeel. Definitely one of the best doppelbocks. Thanks to joss for this one.

Bottle.  Color is muddy dark red/brown with a bubbly brown head.  Aroma is salty dark raison and malts.  Taste is dark fruit, malt, doughy, with a little burnt chocolate.  Damn this is good!  I forgot how much I love a good dopplebock.

Grapevine Market - Austin, Tx - 12 oz bottle - Im going to go out on a limb and figure that this is the same as Augustinerbrau Munchen - as it tasted like a Dopplebock to me. Pours a thick, dark, syrupy brown with a molasses like aroma. Flavor has some dates, raisins, brown sugar and baked brown bread. Quite nice. Mouthfeel is thicky and syrupy - quite delighttful. A most delightful little dopplebock.
Pours dark brown with little head fades to a ring of bubbles. Aroma had mostly dark fruits with some malt. Flavor the same with some molaases and a little raisin shows up in finish.
Bottle. Slight ruby/brown colour. Some sticky soy and brown sugar and caramel.  Maybe a bit too sticky for me, as a lot of doppelbocks tend to be. But this was OK, pretty decent.
Dark ruby with a small tan head. Mild malty caramel aroma. Sweet caramel, touch of choc and roast. Medium-full bodied. Nice.
super malty aroma with hints of chocolate, dark red/chocolate brown, rich and malty originally then goes south a bit with a dry caramelly/nutty finish

Thin head with decent carbonation.  Very short head retention.  Rich malty aroma with molasses, caramel and sweet soy sauce.  Color is a deep mahagony red.  Malty flavor with some dark fruits, molasses and a hint of roastyness.  Finish is slightly warming and a bit creamy.  Nothing that stands out with this brew.  Just an all around good beer and a good example of a dopplebock.
Clear brown color with no head. Great aroma of rich malt, dark fruits and soy. Flavor of dark fruits, soy, malt and alcohol. Light body, liquorous texture, soft carbonation.

Well, the guy on the bottle looks pretty happy... and now so am I!  Rich, thick, strong, sugary malt aroma with plenty of dark fruits (raisins, plums, dates).  Clear, dark mahogany with ruby tone and shy, off-white head that recedes to ring.  Notes of roasted malts, soya sauce, sweet, sugary and nutty malts, dates, plums, raisins in the satisfyingly complex flavour.  Medium body with soft, fine-bubbled carbonation that caresses the tongue.  Bottle enjoyed with beerbuzzmontreal, lubiere, MartinT and Rastacouere.

Deep ruby brown body wears minimal head, but displays a nice little haze. Its aroma is rich and bold, claiming for the big leagues in the doppelbock community. Moderately complex flavor suburb ranges from the floral almond skin to the woody and almost cheesy sweet fruits. You bite into that honeymelon only to uncover a grape branch and vinous berries. Upon tasting, I once again am taken aback by more unexpected character showing up in the form of a earthy and roasty bitter finish, though I pass through the fruit and nut appetizer at first. Soft carbonation accompanies the medium body. The global experience remains constructive, more warming toward the end, but as interesting in its unveiling mysteries form the beginning. Interestingly multilayered in its boldness.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2016 The Lure:Wise toasted malt lets maple sweetness and jammy fruitiness shine bright.

The Festivities:Earth-laden caramel blends perfectly with the bready lengths. Maple tree shavings bear brown rum sweetness. Fruit jam character spans from cranberries to cherries and strawberries.

Transcendence:An expertly carved piece is always a beauty to behold even if it does not stray in any form from the conventional.
Im a real dopplebock fan, this is my new favorite.  Rich and malty, but not syrupy like Ayinger Celebrator.  A bit sweet, but unsurpassed in all other respects.
Took half a bottle to get used to.  reminded me of yinpu a little bit without the odd aftertaste.

12 oz bottle.  Deep brick-inflected maple, this geysered out of the bottle but perhaps was just shaken a bit, the beer was fine...head recedes quickly to a small lasting light brown ring...creamy caramel nose with touches of vanilla and port is inviting if typical...the body is rich and creamy, almost milkshake-full, with sweet caramel and bitter chocolate duking it out and some roastiness that is welcome if a bit odd...fairly light, dry bitter finish caps the mostly sweet (caramel wins) body.

Chestnut coppery brown w/ a lasting beige head.  Deeply malty: caramel, raisiny dark fruit, and bready malt.  Very clean with malt dominating.  Toasted malty flavor, well balanced, sweet but not cloying.  Clean, dark fruit (raisiny) w/ light caramel. Semi dry malt flavored finish w/ a light hop aftertaste.  Full bodied, smooth, low carbonation.  Very well hidden alcohol.  Outstanding doppel!!!!  Great example of the style.

honey.  ummmm.  honey.  or metallic.  but honey.  well, maybe..  metallic.  a bit of a schizophrenic brew.  much lighter than its appearance would indicate, though the initial nose of sweet maltiness is apt and true.  not bad.
A hazy dark brown beer with a disappearing light brown head. The aroma is sweet with notes of caramel and hints of alcohol. The flavor is also sweet with notes of caramel and a little chocolate.
Dark brown with a foamy light tan head. Yeast and fruit aroma with toffee and chocolate tones. Flavor is sweet sugary and rather cloying. Too sweet in the long run.
UPDATED: AUG 15, 2005 Bottle @ RBESG2005. Dark chewey malts in the nose. Dark brown body with a ruby tint, small tan head. Loads of dark malts and prunes in the flavor.
Decent ordinary beer. I would not call this a Doppelbock. It is way too thin to be that in my opinion.

Bottled: DArk amber coloured. LIght brown head. Aroma is malty and sweet and has some fruity notes. flavour is fruity and light spicy with some malty notes. Alcahol not overlky well covered. Neat little beer.
Pours a deep red and a small tan head.  Aroma is small and very sweet.  Flavor is malty and woody with some notes of brown sugar.   Good but not the best of its kind but it is quite tasty.
12 oz bottle: Pours very dark with a tan head. Very thick consistancy. Tastes very fruity, with an unusual aftertaste. Good beer, but Ive had better.

Darkness warshed over The Dude. This beer is dark with hints of red. Flavor is quite complex. Starts with dark chocolate, follows with cherries, and finishes with a zap of vanilla extract. Only complaint is that it ends up a little too sweet. Great beer though!

Well this one I tried at Augustiner, on draught, not bottled.the Aroma was mild yet intense malts - a contadiction in terms I know, but accurate. The head as you would expect with a draught brew was light and subsided mostly, but retained a little even at the end of the glass. The flavour was decidedly veinous, mildly hoppy, the flavour lingering with hints of liquorice in the background ending with a faint sherbet like taste. No stickiness was evident. Not bad at all, hic....

Dark brown, scant tan head. Bready aroma. Roast, fruit, wood, very slight dry bitterness. Medium body I agree with Probiere, quite portlike. This might, like port, be very good with some high-cacao chocolate. Excuse me for a moment while I get out a piece of the Lindt 85%... Oh wow. Thats a darn good combination.

Great super dark tea color, little head.  Big bread and toffee, some chocolate, big yeast smell.  Taste raisins and dust, brown sugar, dusty finish?  Dryish...bitter chocolate, like a super permium bar?  Medium body with oily feel.  Port-like when warm.

Pours reddish brown with a medium tan head. Aroma is steeped in caramel and malt with some hints of fruit and brown sugar. Taste is more caramel and brown sugar mixed with malt. Sweet taste but very smooth. Not overdone or too sweet to be tolerated. Like a smoother Paulaner Salvator. Mouthfeel is generally smooth with a sweet finish. Sort of sticky as well. Some bready notes towards the end. Damn good beer!
Is it a triple or a bock?  Seems to balnce between the two styles.  Great at room temperature, thick, and dark.  Sip and enjoy.

Bottle. Poured cola brown with medium sized tan head. Aroma was a nice mix of dates, prunes, nuts and yeast. Taste was a bit odd of too much of that dried fruit and caramel. Sweet and sticky without any real bitterness.

Bottle, tulip glass.  Average sized, creamy, off-white, diminishing head.  Clear, dark, brown-ruby body.  Caramel and chocolate malt (H); date and brown sugar aromas.  Heavily sweet throughout with a long, sweet aftertaste.  Medium body, oily/slick texture, soft carbonation.  The bottom line is: very brown sugary sweet with a nice bitter chocolate finish/aftertaste.
dark caramel aroma.  sweet, woody.  raisins, a tad smoky.  a nice complex doppleblock flavor.  syrupy smooth.  a very good dopplebock.
UPDATED: OCT 22, 2007 Dark ruby color with a small tan head. Sweet aroma of toffee, raisons and fruit. Flavor is sweet with toffee and tootsie roll.

Deep ruby brown color, medium off white head. Has a fruity/raisin aroma, with roasted malt, bananas that have begun to brown, and pumpkin. Medium body for the style, sweet, flat carbonation, slightly acidic, harsh metallic taste at times, especially in the finish.
a very nice strong beer.  sweet but still have a nice kick to it.  could easily find the alcohol,  but it still fit the beer well.

Bright brown with a garnet tint when held to the light. Small dense mocha colored head. Molasses and dry sherry aromas. Touch of grass in the background. Smooth, silky and rich in feel. Initial malt sweetness with light malt and caramel flavors to follow. A light smoke/caskwood dryness in the finish. Almost too smooth.
Brown,slightly hazy, small brown head.  Lots of fruity malt, figs, raison and prunes type flavors.  Sweet.  Body is syrupy and thick.  Finish is very sweet.  Good Dobbelbock.
Nice brown color. Malty aroma. Lots of malt flavor. Very roasty. Good beer.
Nice brown color with tan head and clear. Carmel malty aroma, with alcohol hints. Big malty flavor, with roasty notes. Decent and enjoyable.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Nice fruity aroma and pours very dark with a small, light brown head. Taste is pretty full as it's pretty thick and has a significant amount of a fruit taste to its flavor. Ends with a chocolately aftertaste and a hint of coffee. Not too bad. Similar to Dogfish Head Immort Ale.

Dark brown in colour, a small amount of ruby highlights are noticeable however. A unattractive off-white SUPER-large bubbled head tops the beer and fades fast. Aroma of strong raisins, caramel, soy sauce, grapes, malt and alcohol. Medium to Full-bodied; Chewy mouthful with a bunch of sweetness. Soon after the sugars hit the palate, some of the meatiness of the soy sauce becomes evident and then fades to a metallic maltiness. Aftertaste shows a bunch of the bittering characteristics of this one, and hardly any of the sweetness. Overall, this one changes over the 'sip lifecycle', but not too pleasant throughout! I bought this 33 cL bottle from Beers of the World in Rochester, New York and sampled it on 16-December-2003.
Intensely sweet dopplebock - superthickbodied - has some woodsy (oaky) aroma and some roasty flavor elements, but - did I mention this is sweet and thick? 3/5 from the SS pack by BHB!!!
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Dark ruby brown with a small tan head.  Sweet intensely caramel bock aroma.  Body has decent complexity dark fruit, caramel malt, and toffee.  Nice thick syrupy texture.  A very smooth, quite drinkable doppelbock, but somewhat one-sided.

Absolutely lovely deep ruby, almost a bit purplish. No head whatsoever. Intensely sweet malty aroma with the slightest edge of cloves and spice. Thick and a bit syrupy on the palate. Extremely delicate carbonation, almost none in fact. Raisins, molasses, and brown sugar are all readily apparent. Slightly vinous. Notes of oak, cherry, and a touch of toffee become more prominent as the beer warms. A tour de force of malt.

This was just a big beer.  Full of sweet dark fruit flavors, a nice malt presence, and some residual lacing.  The aroma has alot of alchohol in it, but the flavor masks it very well.  Sweet and full-bodied and something I would drink over and over again.
Very dark, with no head at all when poured. Syrupy with a hint of alcohol presence. A slight fruitiness. Sweet and fairly full bodied. I would try this again.
Massively sweet, flat, thick brew with hints of alcohol and tangy acidity.  Too sweet for my tastes, I elected to pour out the last 1/3.
Sweet, cereal, and sour flavors.  Mostly yeasty and cereal grain nose.  Some tart flavors, but dominated with a syrupy sweet flavors.  No real hop presence to be found.
Very malty, molasses, chocolate.  Medium, tan head, dark brown body.  Sweet and chewy.  Start drinking it slightly chilled and see how it changes at it warms.  Very good beer!

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2007 Bam!  This beer is huge - dark, dark brown with intense carbonation - nose full of molassas, brown sugar and dates - flavor contains the same, with hints of espresso and cookie dough - this beer straight-up kicks ass - if you dont like it, there is clearly something wrong with you.

This beer pours a dark brown color with a small creamy head and no lacing on the glass.  The aroma is very malty with a coffee/chocolate hint to it.  The flavor was very smooth.  Very little carbonation and very rich mouthfeel.  There is also a hint of fruityness in the flavor that is very nice.  I really enjoyed this beer and will do so again.
Has a dark ruby color with some carbonation and a malted smell.  Taste is very malted and finishes very smooth.  Overall a great doppelbock.  These are becoming my favorite beers.

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2007 Blackened burgundy.  Filtered.  Creamy ring of dusty white foam.  Elegant aroma of figs and cream, concord grape, molasses, spice cake, slightly burnt sugar, and leather.  Boisterous meaty malts and lightly vinous.  Faint earthy notes paired with notes of chocolate, perfume, smoke, and prunes.  Slick textured mouthfeel.  Miniscule carbonation.  Rich prune flavors followed by spicy alcohol, molasses, black cherry, earthy notes, grainy/sticky sugar, and light milk chocolate.  Lingering dark grape flavors alongside a rich, savory, jellied malt base.  An astonishing exhibition of luxurious malts. And it achieves such complexity with a subdued hop presence.  Stellar.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Thick pour,dark oarnge/brown. Fizzy,carbonation forms a head,but it doesn't last.Huge doughy,fruity,sweet, malt nose.Vinous as well. Mouthfeel is thick,creamy, with subtle carbonation.Starts a little empty,but quickly dark bread,and thick,sweet malts develop.Fruity,sweet finish,with lingering earthy flavors. Maybe just a hint of oxidation in the finish.Doesn't detract.Strong,thick, and easy to drink.

Oh boy was this the perfect end to a night of german beer tasting. Pours and looks like dark motor oil. Drinks like oil as well, not that there is anything wrong with that. The oily (someone said syrupy) mouthfeel is intense with flavors of malty sweetness. Not for chugging. Alcohol is evident but not overpowering.

This Dopplebock poured a medium tan head that dissolved quickly and it contained fine-medium bubbles. There was no lacing on the sides of my glass. The body was dark brown. It had a sweet aroma to it. The taste was very smoooth and this was a Dopplebock that I enjoyed drinking. Dopplebock are sooooo good!!

This brew poured a medium head of finely sized light brown bubbles and asemi-opaque dark brown body.  It has a very nice medium strength malt aroma with a very good malt Doppelbock flavor.  It is very smooth from start to finish, slightly sweet and leaves a slight tingling sensation in the aftertaste.
Dark copper-brown with a malty aroma. Flavor is rich and malty with some bitterness in the dry hop finish.
Very good, but I didn't get enough to make a proper rating- more coming soon.

deep red brown color,  a good tan  three finger head.
 sweet malt aroma with caramel and butter notes.
full bodied,
rathersweet taste, fullof caramel , chocolate, cherry preserves.  has a pleasant brandy- like alcohol  burn. 
a solid wel made doppelbock.

Very dark red brown body topped by a medium thick tan head with good lace.  Sweet caramel and malt aroma with fruity characters and a slight alcoholness.  Slightly sweet caramel and malt flavor with coffee notes and a touch of alcohol.  Full bodied, relatively smooth and warming.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2005 Nutty toffee aroma, slightly hoppy.
Deep brown, creamy brown head.
Oily sticky mouthfeel in the aftertaste, perhaps this is only evident because the tastenotes are rather light and exit fast. Easy accessable Doppelbock.
Vertical tasting against 2 year old one:The old Maximator has gained a sweet oak and port aromanote (would get an 8), but has lost the fruity berrylike freshness of the young beer. Sweet wooden notes are more pronounced in the old one, however the mouthfeel is thinner. The young one feels rounder.
Carbonation is still good in the old one and it has a roasted wooden aftertaste.

Pours a deep brown color with brilliant garnet hues seeping through.  The aroma is an interesting blend of sweet, chocolatey malts, dark fruits and a hind of dry cereals.  I agree with the sticky consistency.  Very thick and full.  I would go for a little more carbination if it was me, but I'm not trying to complain.  The flavor is comprised strongly of sweet malts, chocolate syrup, cherries, a bit of roasted character, and maybe a hint of smoke.  Another nice doppelbock and a great beer.

Sticky.  The commercial description is right - I'm sticky from drinking this; i've got that "smackety-smack" sticky lips thing and my fingers are sticking to the keyboard.  Very malty - full of chocolate covered cherries (not the cordial kind - more like bing cherry covered with hershey's special dark)  The one minor fault I found with this brew was that the palate seemed too thin and fizzy - not in line with the flavors.  On the other hand, this "lightness" of palate makes you want to drink it a little too fast!  Hooray for Maximator!

Nice dark color that wasn't to terribly dark.Aroma was malty with some coffee,chocolate,and raisan in it.Flavor was definately big and syrupy,sweet malt,raisan with a hint of prune in it.nice sweet finish with a dark roasted malt aftertaste that is very pleasant.Still this is one of those brews that cost so much that it's a once in a blue moon trial,but very well done.
Chocolate & Malty aroma.  Deep, dark color.  This is such a good beer, and great for the style.  Hints and raisen and tasted grain.
Big molasses malt in nose and mouth with familiar raisin, toasty caramel, etc.  Same idea as Optimator, but I like this a bit more.

Dark reddish brown. Aroma is malty and sweet. Flavor is sweet with molasses or perhaps brown sugar. This is a pretty good doppelbock. I was impressed. I was sceptical because of the labeling and how it's on the bottle crooked. But this was a quality brew.

Sweet and tangy malts. Molasses and brown sugar, bit of raisins. Some hops and worty, licorice. In all, nice aroma. Small tan head, thin with no lacing. Color of flat dark root beer. Medium high carb. Body is heavy watery to chewy. Taste is malty and kind of sweet up front. Hops come in to finish, but overall a bit watery albeit flavorful. Taste doesn't hang around and very little after - a dull sweetness. An OK doppelbock but doesn't really "grab" you.

i´m not a big doppelbock fan but this really agreed with me. certainly beats amsterdam maximator. burnt amber with a big soapy head. aroma starts as salted raisins with some paint stripper, salted licorice, chocolate and Lynx Africa. taste started burnt-bitter, burnt lychees and then smoothed - some brandy, and finishes with burnt black bean and rotten peach. texture softens - Allowrie butter. great stuff - a bottle of this was a journey

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2003  This is a typical quality dopplebock, body is much better than Paulaner and Spaten stuff lately. Salvator looks and tastes more like a deep marzen/bock than the old black stuff. Stick with this or Celebrator of the widely available German DBocks.

Dark ruby brown color with only a small edge head.  Thick, malty nose with a mild roasted caharacter.  Lots of bread and sticky sweetness.  Molassesy and rummy with an alcohol bite near the finish.  No hop presence.  Not cloying.  Very good.

Dark red-brown with small beige head.  Aroma is sweet, cherry and caramel, with a bit of alcohol.  Flavor is sweet and very malty, with cherry and molasses characteristics.  Alcohol presence, but not overwhelming.  Chewy body.
Brownish color. Soft and very drinkable, pleasure to have it. Nice complexity as well. Recommended

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2009 2009 resample in Munich.  Golden-amber with no head.  Brown sugar.  Nice little aroma and good raisiny notes.  Rich, malty character.  Very cool toffee notes with a hint of toast. Old rate, 2002:  Dark brown w/red highlights.  Thick malt aroma w/cherries, brown sugar, alcohol; very thick, molassesy, earth tones, chewy.  Good doppelbock for those who like the style. 7-2-7-3-14 = 3.3
This brew is soo malty I cant even drink it. I guess I should have expected this. Not something I would ever drink again. Way too malty, no good!

Dark and lovely with a small thin foam head.  Nice hearty and fruity aroma.  Very malty flavor, middle finish with sweet hints.  Very smooth mouthfeel.  A good beer in a great tradition of Doppelbocks.
Very sweet and delicious.  Well crafted.  Lots of alcoholic kick to it.  True to its style.
A realy good doppelbock, not quite as good as celebrator, but not too far from it. Has a great sweet malty taste and smooth mouthfeel. I am impressed.
This is a very smooth doppelbock.  Nice malty aroma, an excellent dark red color, and a pleasant light tan head.  Very smooth and easy to drink, this is quite a good beer, and well worth trying.
It tasted a lot like the other doppelbocks Ive had (Celebrator, Optimator, Salvator), just as good as those.  Well not as good as Celebrator, but close.

I found it to be fairly creamy and easy to drink. It wasnt bitter as some darker beers often are, and I found it to be one of the few dark beers outside of the British Isles that impressed me. May not be in the top tier, but definately worth checking out as one of the German beers.

deep tootsie-roll brown; with a head the color of old newspaper,  ample and responsive . big pumpernickel malt nose, a delight for us malt-heads: figs and turkish coffee, old steamer trunks and absynthe. just a trace of wet leaves from the forest floor suggesting a rather mature bottle--if you took this beer to the movies it would qualify for a discount.  still spry though with a sweet coffee flavor, crisp palette, full bodied enough to stretch out your cheeks like dizzy gillespie. a touch more hops would make it orally orgasmic, they register just enough bitterness to keep it from being a runaway malt orgy.
Big molasses/dark fruit aroma, the head quickly goes away, starts with a fizzy palate, but quickly becomes less so.  Similar to, although (IMHO) not as good as Celebrator.
What a name!  Sounds like an Arnie character.  This is a good, powerful malty beer.  Watch out, its sweet malts hide a strong brew.
Not my favorite doppel but worth seeking out.

I dont quite get the average rating of 3.94.  I picked this one up because it ended in ator and was labelled as dark, so I could only assume its a Doppelbock, which I like when done really well.  This reminds me a lot of the H.C. Berger Dopplebock . . . sweet, and flat.  (And, yes, the Berger is really spelled Dopplebock.)  Nice, sweet, coffee-like (and fruit-like) touch in the aroma, but like the Berger, it falls flat for the most part elsewhere.  Nice flavor, but just really flat.  Brownish-black color, pretty standard for a good doppel.  Head disappears very quickly.  I have to warn you: if you dont like highly sweet beers, you wont like this.  I like it myself, but I like sweet beers.  But it disappoints to the extent that it doesnt have a robustness to it that you get in the Ayinger Celebrator or Weltenburger Asam-Bock, the only two doppels Ive tried that really impress me.  Like the Berger, Id put this around a 3.5.  Actually may not be as flat as the Berger, but still could have been crafted better.  Alcohol content is pretty pleasing, though.

I was introduced to this beer by an employee at my local ale merchant.  I was in the process of purchasing some Celebrator (never having tried it) and he told me that this was better and cheaper to boot.  I have to admit that it is less expensive, but definitely not better.  Still, I like the maltiness.  The hops are hidden ... I almost wonder if the bitterness isnt a derived from the malt.  I like this beer.  It is quintessentially German.  But I wouldnt recommend it to everyone.  It takes a familiarity and appreciation of German styles to really enjoy.  Still, I would love to quaff a few of these around Octoberfest season.

Wow, simply wonderful. Dark, malty, fruity complexity with a kick but a smooth finish that hides the alcohol. Wish i could get my hands on more but not sold in Oregon, thanks to my friend Mike for bringing me this.
Dark, rich, a bit bitter in the aftertaste. Among the best dopplebocks Ive tasted. Like blessed Augustine himself, predestined for glory.
Very pretty dark brown, with a great head. Slight roasty metallic taste that detracts from it, however, it has many redeming qualities. Medium mouthfeel. Light, caramel/sweet taste.

Second only to Celebrator.  Lush prune and chocolate aroma accompany the malty prune, plum, and chocolate flavors.  Dark cherry red with little head, alcohol was detectable but otherwise a non-factor before the slightly bitter, coffee-grind, hop and yeast finish. Kudos also for the body, which could have been syrupy and cloying, but instead was near-perfectly suave.
My friend said it tasted like dog food. Hes a moron. Hopefully, he will never read this review.

This dopplebock might be better than Celebrator. Wish I could get my hands on another bottle for resampling.
